Title: Duuuudes, go see it!..
Review:
For a long time, I was (and still am) skeptical about Disney movies, whichever size and shape they come in. About 7 minutes into this one I was saying to myself, "The artwork is amazing, CG (*I'm a computer person, so I yearn for really cool, CPU-intensive CG*) is totally unrivaled, but the story line sucks so bad, why I am watching another Disney tear-squeezer??"

Well, looks like after 15 minutes of run time Pixar guys had a brief meeting and said, "Screw you, Disney, we are not letting you ruin another one!"

Please -- bear for exactly 15 minutes of the most syrupy kindergarten stuff (stunning visuals will help you, though you might feel guilty about watching this while wide awake, instead, say, shoveling the snow), and watch the 199% predictable slop explode into one of the most ironic, witty, and -- did I mention that? -- beautifully constructed CG cartoons of all time.

Did you like "Shrek"? Well, this is not exactly "Shrek" material, but still IMDB 10 grade. Just because IMDB gives you only 10 points to choose from. On a scale of 100, "Shrek" would be 100, and "Nemo" would pull about 92.

Just sit back, settle yourselves; I repeat, you'll need to watch the first 15 minutes to grasp the plot (though not necessarily, there's enough redundancy in the dialogs for the late-comers (or the denser crowd)), and enjoy -- really enjoy! -- the rest.

You will see a couple of scenes where the Disney managers came back and tried to ruin (sorry, save! of course, save from the hand of perverted Pixarians!) the movie, but these episodes were only mildly irritating and quickly dissolved themselves without overall damage to the spectacular, weird and funny world of talking, blinking, breathing, flirting fish.

Worth to watch. Most probably worth to own, if anything, just to watch your favorite little charming scenes again and again.

Enjoy, /D

Title: Excellent!
Review:
A must-see movie for kids of all ages.

Disney/Pixar Studios outdid themselves once again. The animation is flawless and the special effects are astonishing (notice the water, close to the surface). The humor is sharper as ever, similar to the one you saw in Monsters, Inc.

The character's voices, specially in the case of Ellen DeGeneres', couldn't be better.

Even the soundtrack, composed by Randy Newman's cousin, Tom, is amazing. Robbie Williams' version of Bobby Darin's classic "Beyond the Sea" gives the soundtrack a final touch.

10 stars for this one, no doubt about it. If you have kids, take them to the theater to watch it. If you don't, go anyway. You won't regret it.

Title: Great fun, always entertaining
Review:
Finding Nemo is a modern animated masterpiece

I found this film thoroughly entertaining from start to finish! First of all the animation was fantastic, truly admirable. When the movie first came out, I immediately began to compare Finding Nemo to other recent animated classics (a la Shrek, Monster's Inc.) and found that it was surely a worthy adversary. Its plot, dialogue, and animation are all very original and Pixar seems to be always striving for a higher goal. Animators didn't simply do what had been done over and over again many times, but came up with something new and fresh to give audiences. And boy does it pay off.

Not to mention Finding Nemo's enormous success in the box office, I have yet to hear someone nay-saying about this movie. This film can be enjoyed by anyone, any age. Animated movies are beginning to evolve to appeal to a variety of audiences, and Finding Nemo is a very good example. The comedic dialogue is hilarious on many levels, for kids and parents alike, which gives it added appeal and all the more fun. I also found the sloo of characters all unique and funny in their own simple way. Dory, Nemo, Marlin, Bruce (the shark), Nigel (the pelican), and Crush (the turtle) are all very different, original, and hilarious characters that bring something differnt to the table. Also, the fact that the writers present several ironies and stereotypes to this characters adds to their hilarity; vegetarian sharks, surfer turtles, clownfish that aren't funny, mindless hungry seagulls, the list can go on and on.

In conclusion I found Finding Nemo original, hilarious, and fun for everybody; truly everybody. 4 out of 5.

Title: The Best Pixar Movie (minor spoilers)
Review:
I'll be totally honest and confirm to you that everything what they say about this movie is true. It's a brilliantly animated masterpiece with lots of humor that actually works and a plot that really brings tears to your eyes from time to time. The modern artists of Pixar never cease to amaze the audience in expanding their horizons. Finding Nemo is visually stunning and you can have nothing but respect for the people who created it.

I was more or less skeptic about watching it, because it was so overhyped ! Two days before it got released in my country, the TV and press loudly announced that the DVD broke all records in the USA during its first release-day. That's usually a sign of being typically mainstream and fake...but Finding Nemo is not. I'm allergic to fake sentiment and pathetic feel-good movies but I was really touched by this one. The moral and valuable life lessons are always present, but they're not shoved down your throat or thrown in your face all the time. This movie really relativates itself and that's important for a good comedy. And it's hilarious !!! Every side character in Finding Nemo (and there are a LOT of them) is exceptional and worth a mention. And the voices are cast perfectly as well...like the voice of Willem Dafoe for Gill, for example...a perfect choice. The character of Dory ( speaks through the voice of Ellen DeGeneres ) steals the show. She's an adorable blue fish who suffers from amnesia. She forgets what she's doing or going to every five minutes and that really leads to hilarious situations.

Movies like this aren't just being made for children exclusive... They're good for everyone to realize you have to entertain yourself from time to time and just to enjoy the little things in life. I recommend this to everyone in the world. No matter if you're 9 or 99 years old, Finding Nemo will bring a smile on your face and leave behind a warm feeling in your heart.

Title: Amazing
Review:
Absolutely amazing movie. Disney/Pixar have definitely out-done themselves. The animation must get an A++ as well as everything else. The plot line was great, and they couldn't have picked better actors/actress' for the voices. A must see. I assure you that you will not be disappointed. I'll be seeing it again for sure. 2 thumbs up! 10 stars!

Title: Nothing fishy about it: 'Finding Nemo' is an animated classic
Review:
The 21st century has had its share of high-tech enhanced flicks, but the "Lord of the Rings" trilogy and Pixar's "Finding Nemo" have proven that it is the inclusion of compelling characters and wonderful stories that makes for a great movie.

"Finding Nemo" has everything a discerning moviegoer could hope for. Ellen DeGeneres's Dory and Albert Brooks' Marlin are perfect casting and this movie will lure in audiences of all ages. Hook, line and sinker.

Title: Not Bad, But It's no Toy Story
Review:
Finding Nemo was clever, cute, well written and definitely a technical advance in animated story telling. It doesn't compare, however, to the first Pixar film I viewed - Toy Story.

My main complaint is that the story moves through so many locations (if I can use that term for an animated movie), that by the end, everything seems rushed. While I understand that the whole premise of the story is a journey, the writers might have been better off spending more time in three or four locales, than hurrying through 10+. That said, my daughter loved it!

6/10 (my daughter, 10/10)

Title: Pixar's Best...
Review:
I have just returned from the most exciting movie I've seen in a long time! Finding Nemo is Pixar's BEST movie, replacing Toy Story (I know, I know, but its true) as the most visually imaginative animated movie. Its funny, DeGeneres is hilarious - her fish is perfectly animated, Brooks is sooooo much better than in the In-Laws, back to his true form - I loved every minute of this film. The celebrity voices are great; Allison Janney from West Wing is a wonderful starfish, Willem DeFoe, always a seductive voice, is a scar worn Tang, even the movie's creator, Andrew Stanton was greatness as the sea turtle Crush. This is one G rated film that is definitely for everyone, any age, any circumstances - see this alone, on a date, with your family - just go...I was swept away with not knowing what was going to happen next, the colors and visuals and the realisation of the sea - the humour, the storyline (a Dad prevails!) all add up to an A+, #1, Best Picture of the Year achievement. Applause, applause, applause to Pixar once again!

Title: One of the best children's movie in a long time...
Review:
Finding Nemo has some of the best lessons to be learned. It was maybe a little more personal to me because I have a close relative (child) with a handicap similar to Nemo's. It has the tragedy (almost as heartwrenching as The Lion King), but it is a sweet, wonderful story about learning how to let go and how to understand and accept other people for who they are.

Title: Great Adventure- Unfunny
Review:
I saw Finding Nemo today- I've been meaning to see it. I expected a great comedy. I was disappointed.

In case you've been living under a rock (or don't have TV) you've probably seen commercials for this. You also probably know that Marlin, a clownfish, has lost his son. With the help of Dory, he is determined to find Nemo, his son.

It has lots of colorful characters that I enjoyed watching. Each of the tank fish are equally unique. My favorite is Peach, probably.

The settings are very creative. The EAC is hilarious and imaginative, as well as the Jellyfish Forest.

The only problem I had is that is it's only mildly funny. It's awfully sad.

The Bottom Line: A wildly creative, mildly funny adventure! Two out of Four Chili Peppers!

Title: A worth while animation
Review:
The underwater sequences where spectacular, enriched with bright colors and fantastic effects. The story line was a little to simple for me and yet is probaly the best family adventure of the year with a light humour that gets all of the little kids laughing at every bump of a fish which can get a little irritating at the cinemas.

I take pride in being an Australian and it was good to see pixar getting real Australian's to do the voice's instead of some American impersonator's that give Australia a far from reality accent. Even with the Aussie actors the aussie slang was used far to often than what it is in reality. Really, why would a well educated dentist be calling people "sheila" and saying "crikey" and "mate" in every sentence. Anyway sheila is an old school word that only the middle aged bogens use these days. And crikey is Steve Irwins word. Not the best movie ive every seen id say it rate about 7/10

Title: Mine!
Review:
Excellent movie! I'm not a big fan of animation, specially Disney movies, but this one was great! Funny characters (except Marlin, "for a clownfish. he's not that funny"), topped by Ellen DeGeneres as Dory. She has the perfect voice for the part.

The story isn't that original (man looking for his son after losing him because of a fight) and parents with really young children might have a problem explaining what happens to Coral at the start of the movie, but the characters that Marlin meets are just hilarious. Sharks, jellyfish turtles, pelicans and seagulls (My favorites: Mine!) all help him out with his quest, or form some obstacle on the way. Must see movie!

Title: Houseful of computers seeks storyteller
Review:
Toy Story again, but with fishes.

1 idea, 2 movies..... I'm getting really sick of this - GO TAKE A CREATIVE WRITING CLASS, YOU IDIOTS!

Yes, but some truly *amazing* visuals, as always - there must be *something* there to make you part with your hard-earned. (and some parts of that something, for some reason, look very much like a screensaver common in Win98 days that I saw here and there... ??!!!! Maybe Pixar look for their inspiration in more mundane (and obvious!) places than I thought?.... :) )

Enjoy on TV, friends places and the like. DON'T PART, etc., etc.,....

Title: Best In a Long Time
Review:
Okay, I admit it, I am a Disney fan, so deal with it.

That being said, "Finding Nemo" was one of the most enjoyable shows I have seen in a long time. I found the story line to be very well written, and extremely tight, with very little dead time on the screen.

There characters were superb, the graphics stunning and the ending so very typically Disney (not a bad thing.) I found myself smiling and laughing throughout the show.

This one is great for the kids, yet still entertaining for the adults!

The Crazed Viking

Title: Eh...
Review:
There's no way this movie is better than "The Deer Hunter," "Notorious," or any of the other movies that have recently been edged out of the top 100 list. It was a nice movie, the animation was very fluid, and I wasn't bored, and that's about all I can say in favor of it. If you want even the slightest intellectual stimulation, search elsewhere, but if you're interested in having a basic message pounded into your head throughout the course of the an hour and a half, then by all means give it a try.

Title: Make that 5 for 5 for Pixar in 8 years!
Review:
Outstanding! Disney and Pixar are a perfect match now for the 5th time straight!!

This movie has everything. The best digital animations to date, the story is classic yet intropective with a grand parental charm and wit coupled with brave and ingenious relationships, genuine heart-felt characters and a clean sweeping pace to the story.

It was a tremendous 2 hours of movie magic at its very best. I highly recommend this film. I can't wait for the dvd we will buy it and cherish it for years just as we do with Bugs life, the Toys Story's and Monsters Inc. have entertained us as well. This is a new level though, the water surface is incredible and real looking. New fresh look and feel for Pixar and Disney. My three year old and my 11 year old as my wife and I loved this film!!!

This is by far the best yet from Pixar/Disney. Thanks for raising the bar guys! A definate 10 out of 10!!!

-can I see it again, -please?!

Title: Go Dory
Review:
Ellen Degeneres is FANTASTIC as the voice of Dory in this movie, she totally makes the movie. Her character keeps you laughing from beginning to end, even during the parts where you feel like crying! She has a lot of talent, and the role was perfect for her sense of humor. The rest of that case also does an excellent job, I felt as if Disney made a quality effort to make this just as enjoyable for adults as for children, except for the poor little boy that sat behind me in the theater, "It's too scary Mommy, I wanna go home!" All of the other children really seemed to be having a good time.

Title: Heart-warming journey of Rescue
Review:
The undersea adventure that Pixar presents is undoubtedly more fleshed out than Disney's "Little Mermaid". The characters are 'human', not just the bland sidekicks found in Disney movies, and the society of "Fish Predators Anonymous" was hilarious. Willem Dafoe is brilliant as the morose Gill.

I appreciate the factual detail in the movie. It is set in the Great Barrier Reef - *it* is the largest structure in the world built by living creatures, not New York - the East Australian Current does lead to New South Wales, clown fish are abundant near the Reef, and there are toxic jellyfish off the Northern coast of Australia. It was nice to listen to the marine life speaking with aussie accents.

But for the fifth time running, a Pixar movie is about a journey of rescue. The formula seems to be wearing out. There are obvious comparisons to be made with Miyazaki, who manages to come up with highly original themes each time a movie is made, making each of them a success. Why do Disney and Pixar not follow the lead? [And, how is a fart joke, good humour?]

Title: Two thumbs way, way up! Pixar shines again!
Review:
I confess, I wasn't sure about Finding Nemo from the trailers. I was a little worried that this was a classic case of all the laugh lines being packed into a 2 minute version of the film.

Let me reassure you, it's not the case. The film is very funny - a laugh a minute - and over way, way too soon. The visuals are beautiful, the undersea depiction is for the most part true-to-life, the story is good, and the message is worthwhile.

In short, I loved it. Keep 'em coming, Pixar, while you've still got the magic in you!

Title: Following in the footsteps of Shrek, NEMO exceeds in humor
Review: Well, I can honestly say... I'm 23 and a guy, yet for one reason or another I find myself put in these situations to watch Children's movies. I've seen Shrek, which I loved. Now, I've seen Finding Nemo, which I love MORE. Ellen Degeneres had me, as well as other adults there with their children, cracking up throughout the movie and I'm not afraid to admit it. While I hate Albert Brooks with a passion, he was perfect for the role of Nemo's father (voice wise). He, however, was the only character I hated. But I loved all the Tank Fish, and Dory, and the Sharks, & others were all wonderful. I think any open minded person who can enjoy a laugh, or who can remember their youth, would enjoy this movie. For Children it is a fun cartoon full of adventure and surprise. For Adults it is a great movie that makes you reflect on your youth, and if you are a parent, yourself as a parent. It also gives you laughs you'd never expect to have in a movie like this. While Shrek was meaningful and romantic, Finding Nemo was hilarious and really got you into it and has another message to get to everyone and I HIGHLY Recommend you see this before it leaves theatres, and if it's too late.. Go out and get it on DVD ASAP, for yourself OR your Children.

Title: Realistic Animation
Review:
Pixar has done an outstanding job on this one. For the last few years I have found out that every time I go to see an animated movie, it seems more realistic. The computer graphics are extremely fine tuned to match the character's personality and voice. The movie is inspiring on various levels. Firstly, the strong bonding between a father and son is depicted with exceptional clarity. The first school-going experience is so close to human experience that kids can immediately relate to it. It makes one wish , every kid had a affectionate and daring father like Marlin. For those kids (or adults) who have'nt known a father's love, the father-son scenes could be quite emotional. Secondly, the general underlying message of preserving marine life in its pristine form is well conveyed. The current commercial fishing practice of trawling the ocean floor clean with utter disregard to any life is shocking to say the least. I hope people and governments take notice and do something to prevent the destruction of the last frontier on this planet. Overall the movie is thoroughly enjoyable whether you are kid or an adult.

Title: Up there with The Nightmare Before Christmas and Toy Story.
Review:
When I originally saw the poster for this film (big empty space with a single fish), I instantly wanted to watch it, as I thought it was just beautiful. However, then I saw the trailers, and thought it just looked like a typical cutesy disney kids film.

Today I watched it on VHS, and realised that my original ideas of what it would be like were indeed accurate. Within five minutes of the film starting, we given one of the most emotive scenes I've ever seen in a children's film, and it actually makes you feel stupid for getting so worked up over a film which is meant for children!

The story is predictable, which is understandable as I doubt Pixar wanted to bewilder the children. However, this is made up for as the character development is great, as we see the isolated culture of the fish tank, and the class system between the different sea creatures (crabs being simple tramps, turtles being richer 'californian' thrillseekers etc.)

The way the film has been made is also great, with the amazing endless underwater landscapes, and the brilliant musical score from Thomas Newman (American Beauty, Six Feet Under). The film has the poetry of Tim Burton's The Nightmare Before Christmas, with the tongue-in-cheek humour of Toy Story, and the emotion of Watership Down, making it one of the best children's films I have ever been fortunate enough to see.

Title: A fantastic movie, about a little fish called Nemo who is swept into adventures above and under the sea!
Review:
A fantastic movie, about a little fish called Nemo who is swept into adventures above and under the sea! Nemo is the only remaining fish after his brothers, sisters, and mother have a dreadful experience with a shark. His father becomes overprotective of Nemo especially after Nemo is taken by a scubadiver and placed in a fish tank at a dentist's office. While wildly searching for Nemo, his father meets a comedic fish who suffers from short term memory loss. The two have adventures under the sea and meet an oceanful of fun!

Title: Amazing Animation, Colorful Characters, Terrific Tale!
Review:
I have always been a Big fan of animated films, ex. Alladin, Beauty and The Beast, Toy Story, etc. Yet, I have felt of late the animated pictures have been lacking the depth in story and the beauty in animation that they once held. Finding Nemo has truly, in my opinion, found those elements again. I was greatly entertained with the films intriguing characters and profound plot. True it is just a cartoon but it was better than your average cartoon: It relayed the message of letting go. Many people know from experience what it is like to loose a loved one and how that loss effects how a person lives his or her life. Finding Nemo relayed this concept in a very gentle and truthful way. A+ Well done Pixar and Disney. Thanks for going back to the good Days.

Title: You'll like it
Review:
I think that this film was beautifully done. The voice talents were perfect for their characters. I think that Helen DeGeneres deserves special mention for her zany character. I'd like to know how much of what she said she made up and how much was scripted. If it was all scripted, she's a genius because her lines sound absolutely spontaneous. The animation was poignant and extremely accurate. It shows that these guys did their marine life homework before making this film. The story is (as most are) an old one of growing up and letting go but I am particularly grateful to the writers for not putting too many fight/nagging scenes as most movies/TV programs do when they use this type of plot. Why they decided for the story to take place in Australia I have no idea but hey, why not? This is truly a universally appealing movie that would be good for anyone to see.

Title: Not up to Pixar's usual standard?
Review:
I finally got around to seeing this on DVD. I was looking forward to it, but I was rather disappointed - compared to Pixar's other work. I don't know how it could be rated higher than either of the Toy story's.

Sure it's technically fantastic, and there are some good moments (Bruce the Shark for example) - but it left me cold. For me there are couple of reasons.

I would say it's the most "Disney like" of all the Pixar films so far (and for me that's a bad thing!) - all rather preachy and predicable. Although at least there was no bursting into song!

I think it could have done with some trims at the editing stage - the film is 20+ mins longer than Toy Story, and you notice it. The Turtle & Jellyfish scenes dragged on, and seemed unnecessary to me.

Let's hope The Incredibles is a return to form for 'older' viewers.

Title: A Find
Review:
The best so far to come out of Pixar-Disney. True to form, the computer-digital effects are fantastic.

Ellen Degeneres is the most talented of the voices we hear in this delightful underwater tale. Her performance allows for her blue tane character, Dory, to come alive in so many beautiful and hilariously entertaining ways.

"Finding Nemo" features numerous sea mines, possessively-hungry seagulls ("Mine, Mine, Mine!") and aquatic acquaintances that reinforce the importance of friendship.

The plot is a rehash of other more familiar Disney films. You won't have trouble listing them. And you won't have to bring the kids with you to watch it. Most of the audience I saw this film with were well over 18yrs of age. Slightly irritating is the fact that the narrative continuously bounces back and forth between the two separated clown fish (Marlin and his son Nemo), and the film appears to run 15 minutes too long for my otherwise liberal attention span.

Title: Cruelest beginning for a kids' movie . . .
Review:
I'll be totally honest and confirm to you that everything what they say about this movie is true. It's a brilliantly animated masterpiece with lots of humor that actually works and a plot that really brings tears to your eyes from time to time. The modern artists of Pixar never cease to amaze the audience in expanding their horizons. Finding Nemo is visually stunning and you can have nothing but respect for the people who created it.

I was more or less skeptic about watching it, because it was so overhyped ! Two days before it got released in my country, the TV and press loudly announced that the DVD broke all records in the USA during its first release-day. That's usually a sign of being typically mainstream and fake...but Finding Nemo is not. I'm allergic to fake sentiment and pathetic feel-good movies but I was really touched by this one. The moral and valuable life lessons are always present, but they're not shoved down your throat or thrown in your face all the time. This movie really relativates itself and that's important for a good comedy. And it's hilarious !!! Every side character in Finding Nemo (and there are a LOT of them) is exceptional and worth a mention. And the voices are cast perfectly as well...like the voice of Willem Dafoe for Gill, for example...a perfect choice. The character of Dory ( speaks through the voice of Ellen DeGeneres ) steals the show. She's an adorable blue fish who suffers from amnesia. She forgets what she's doing or going to every five minutes and that really leads to hilarious situations.

Movies like this aren't just being made for children exclusive... They're good for everyone to realize you have to entertain yourself from time to time and just to enjoy the little things in life. I recommend this to everyone in the world. No matter if you're 9 or 99 years old, Finding Nemo will bring a smile on your face and leave behind a warm feeling in your heart.

Title: A very funny movie
Review:
Rarely have I actually laughed out loud in a movie theater 6 times. Probably the best comedy since, Monty Python and the Holy Grail. The jokes were good for both adults and kids. The second best thing may be that the plot was not just a pretense it actually was nice.

Title: Awe-inspiring animation does not a watchable movie make
Review: First things first. Ellen Degeneres and Albert Brooks aren't funny. They never have been. So when Disney slots this bungling pair as the voices of the two lead characters in FINDING NEMO, then we haven't got much to look forward to. Or have we? After all, the animation is stunning. And once we get past the fact that Degeneres' voice comes from a fish actually modeled to look like her, then it is momentarily possible to get lost in the pixelated splendor of Disney's greatest animating achievement to date. The sea sparkles with the magical touches of what must have been countless talented, tireless animators. But is this enough? The plot stinks like a rancid Freudian family drama. And the missing sexual tension between the two lead characters (both single) is a glaring mistake. But it does have something going for it. Almost every scene on land is fantastic. The comedy is spot on, and the noticeable disparity between good jokes and great timing (on land) and dull, tiresome jokes in the sea (where most of the movie is spent, and where Brooks and Degeneres flounder along, oblivious to their own inanity) make the humor on land seem that much better. Overall, however, the movie is unbearable. It's one thing for it to be unswervingly predictable. Sure, every Disney movie is. But getting from beginning to end doesn't have to seem like a chore, a penance for some wrong that i didn't realize i committed. Or maybe the wrong was simply buying the movie tickets and supporting Disney. And i sure got punished for that.

Title: Pixar have done it again
Review:
After seeing a brief trailer for this on the Monsters Inc dvd,I couldnt wait to see this movie.But I was shocked to find out we wouldnt be getting a release in the UK until October.Luckily for me I had a trip to New York planned so I made sure a visit to the movies was planned.All I could say is wow,it lives up to Pixars high standards and it got a big thumbs up from my eight year old son.Everything from the characters to the animation is nothing short of spectacular,I will certainly be paying another visit to the movies again in October when it is released here.It is just a shame they couldnt have released it here for the summer.But as the saying goes all good things come to those who wait.UNMISSABLE

***** out of *****

Title: Ow yeah incredibly!!!
Review:
Well my favorite Disney film still is Lilo & Stitch but this one is truly going second!

I know I know most of you won't agree with me but I'm a Disney lover of the new generation and the old. And movies like Atlantis the lost Empire, Treasure Planet and especially Lilo & Stitch entertain me just as well as Alladin and the Lion King did for me while I was little!

Finding Nemo is truly great on itself and profits from truly beatifull animation work! The story is adorable and the characters are perfect for young and old! I liked Dory the little female fishy suffering from a short-term memory loss. D0h I also liked Memento would it be because of that?

Well not much to say further, excellent animation, voice acting and a perfect story about a dad who has to look for his sun in the ocean(it's much better as it sounds.)

Disney (Pixar actually) still rules and as long as they keep up the good work I will be watching this movies till I am dead!

**** out of Five!

Title: Giggle
Review:
I thought this was precious. Even if you're not a kid you'll still love it. In every Disney movie I've ever seen there are always jokes that kids will never get but the adults always pick up on. Nemo is no different. And the characters are so funny. There's this one character named Bubbles, he lives in a fish tank and every time this little treasure chest opens it let's out little bubbles. And every time they come out he races over to it screaming "Bubbles! Bubbles! My bubbles!" He's just so funny. And the sea turtles are awesome! Totally. =], anyhow, it's really such a wonderful movie, and you really feel for the characters. All Nemo is trying to do it get home to his daddy. Its so sad, but he's got great friends to help him out! Very cute, A+!

Title: Funny!
Review:
Finding Nemo is a very funny movie!I absolutely loved it.The story follows a father who is overprotective of his son.On the first day of school, Marlin(father) believes that his son,Nemo, is not yet ready for school ,but Nemo thinks otherwise and swims in to open sea and gets fishnapped and Marlin goes in search of him.On the way, he meets a fish with short-term memory loss named Dory and she helps him look for his son.

They also meet a couple of sharks and some totally far out sea turtles.Meanwhile,Nemo is welcomed to a club with a bunch of fish he meets in a tank in a dentists office.And I'll leave the rest for you to watch.

Kids and adults of all ages will most definitely love it.Overall 10/10 stars.

Title: not a classic
Review: Pixar has created a visually stunning animated movie. I could spend all day staring at this great animated aquarium that "Nemo" has delivered. Nemo with its great animation is worth seeing! but only seeing. the fact than many people are calling this a classic makes me wonder what movie they saw. What makes a classic animated movie is a good story and strong characters. I believe Nemo fails on both counts. The story line is a basic one. We follow the path of two fish, nemo and his father marlin as they get seperated and their attempt to reunite. The scenes depicted are nicely done but you feel like you are being swept from one scene to another, the segways are missing. The story line is not deep enough so you can walk away feeling that you missed something in the storyline, which in fact you haven't, there just isn't anything else there. The film is also missing out on strong characters. The main characters would all be considered good supporting charcters, but unfortunately are asked to carry the movie. But in their defense how much character can a fish have? The point being is that finding nemo is a beautifully animated film about fish delivering a bunch of comedic lines telling a simple story that makes you want more than it delivers. To me a classic delivers more than you want.

Title: A Children's Movie???
Review:
I really can't describe my distaste for a children's movie in which you have to skip the entire first scene so as not to give the children nightmares. It really wasn't necessary to SHOW how Nemo and his father came to be alone. The animation is superb, but I expected, after all the build-up I'd read and heard, to hear a lot more laughter from the children watching it. This flick can't hold a candle to "Monsters, Inc."

Title: An Outstanding Movie for All
Review:
"Finding Nemo," is an excellent movie for viewers of all ages. In this movie, three valuable life lessons are shared: 1) parents protect their children because they love and care for them, 2) teamwork is important in being successful, and 3) your differences do not define you. These lessons can apply to viewers of all ages and are presented throughout the course of the movie.

Overall, "Finding Nemo" was nearly flawless. From the outstanding animation, to the talented voices of actors/actresses, to the entertaining jokes and plot, I find this to be one of Disney Pixar's best movies.

Title: Not Pixar's best
Review:
I love the Toy Story movies and enjoyed Monsters Inc., so I was looking forward to Finding Nemo. Unfortunately, Nemo was not nearly as enjoyable as Pixar's other fine movies.

I found very few genuine laughs in Nemo. I thought Dory, a fish with short term memory, was cute and had a few funny moments, but otherwise the movie fell flat. A lot of the jokes were just not funny. Some of the characters were your typical run of the mill cartoon characters, such as the 'surfer-dude' turtle, which I could have done without.

Technically, Nemo looks great. The visuals are good. But, I can't help thinking with the whole underwater world that they could not come up with more dazzling characters other than shark, turtle, whale, etc...

The bottom line is that Nemo is a pretty movie that ends up feeling empty with very few laughs and flat characters. I give it a 5 out of 10.

Title: Brilliant Film
Review:
What can I say about this movie? One word - Brilliant. Pixar have had a long track record of having yet to make anything less than a very good film but even though its almost unanimously agreed that all of them have been great, it seems everyone still has their preferences. To give you an idea of my taste I just adore "A Bug's Life" which I think is pretty much a pitch perfect movie with great characters and story. I enjoyed "Toy Story" but wasn't a huge fan of it, the sequel however is an absolute classic hands down. After 'Bugs' and 'TS2' though came "Monsters Inc" which again was a really good movie but I wasn't a huge fan of as the "Where the Wild Things Are"-cloned concept was fine but like TS1 the film got too juvenile and sentimentally sweet for me with the humor just worth the odd giggle more than anything else and only the awesome 'doors' sequence standing out in my mind.

'Nemo' however has now taken the crown - its at least equal best with TS2 and the more I think about it the more its rising to be stand out Number One. EVERYTHING about this movie is practically flawless - the animation, the characters, the story, the emotional resonance, the humor, etc. is incredible. Its a film you can't help but get swept up in right from the get-go, in fact I can't remember a film where I really ran the gamut of emotions from happy and awed to despair and terror - and this film manages to do all that in just the opening five-minute sequence. Its a 100 minute underwater road movie but never ever gets slow or tired and even some Disney-style father-son sentimentality bits oddly enough generate genuine heart and warmth.

*Ellen DeGeneres deserved an Osar nomination for her flawless performance as Dory.

Title: The Best Piece of Disney and Pixar
Review:
I LOVED THIS MOVIE! You like coke? This movie will make you love water!! The friendly (or not) expressions from the characters, the funny and perfectly matched voices, the story, the idea, and everything is awesome! The soundtrack is what I like the most, maybe. Thomas Newman is for me an inspiration and my distractor (for good) on every occasion! The Ending song makes me wanna cry... And every moment of this movie is preceded by his music, which creates a natural, exotic, and beautiful climate.

About the animation, is Pixar my friends! It's perfect!

I highly recommend this movie. One of my favorites (I saw the latinoamerican Spanish and English version, i liked both a lot!). It's the perfect movie for every occasion, for adults, kids, and teenagers too!

5/5 *****

Title: 2003's Best
Review: The latest in a string of tightly written and superbly animated features from Pixar Studios, who have risen to become gods of animation. Finding Nemo begins with one of the darkest openings in Disney cartoon history, telling the story of a father clown-fish named Merlin who loses his wife and all but one of his hundreds of fish eggs in a tragedy destined to make you think twice about ordering fish and chips for dinner. Marlin becomes the over-protective father of Nemo, his sole surviving child who is kidnapped by a scuba diving dentist and placed in a fish tank in his operating room. Thus the search begins, and Marlin must travel through the Great Barrier Reef to rescue his son, conquering his fears and meeting all sorts of strange and interesting creatures on the way (Bruce, a shark battling a ravishing fish addiction, is particularly memorable) The story thrives on simplicity, riding a singular concept all the way to a gloriously satisfying conclusion, and the script is choc-a-block full of gags and one-liners that are genuinely funny for all ages. This, in fact, is the perfect family movie: gorgeous to look at, tightly wound and high-octane, without a trace of pretension or dumb-downed ideals that so frequently condescend the younger market. Finding Nemo is one of the best animated films ever made, a glorious awe-inspiring tale comparable to classics like The Lion King.

Title: Animation Masterpiece
Review:
I never thought I would rave about a movie about fish. Actually, this story is about much more than that. It is about family and love and a tender relationship between a father and a son. I am not going to lie. At the end of this movie, I really teared up and almost cried. This movie was very heartfelt and it's definitely, without a doubt, the funniest movie I have seen this year.

The casting in this movie was sheer perfection. Brooks and Gould do great as the father and son, but the standout of the movie, is of course, Dory, voiced by the great Ellen DeGeneres. This is the best voice-over work since Robin Williams in Aladdin. A truly stellar voice over job with so many LOL moments. Also great was the 'tank gang,' as I like to call them. Great voice-over works from Garrett, Dafoe, and Janney.

The script for this movie is so fresh and so amazing that it crosses age barriers. It is a simple story that goes very far.

Two 50 year-old, a 19 year-old, and a year-old all laughed equally during this movie. It truly is a movie for all ages. A funny and heart-tugging story for everyone.

Nothing more to say that hasn't already. This is one GREAT movie.

Title: Best pixar movie ever
Review:
I enjoyed this movie very much. I selected it for a movie review in high school and watched it more than 5 times in a row. The ultimate mix, sadness and joy, as usual in Disney movies was certenly included this time.

Title: Animated Greatness
Review:
Finding Nemo contains a message slightly more complex than usually associated with family films, but as written and co-directed by Andrew Stanton, it's eloquently presented in a context that carries it through with potency. Stanton doesn't shy away from trauma -- the film contains its share, including an opening tragedy that rivals the shooting of Bambi's mother, but also pays respect to the precarious and predatory nature of undersea life. Everything is part of the food chain in the nautical world. It's the best circle of life message since Disney's The Lion King.

The film is awash in humor -- the sharks, for instance, are fearsome in their toothy glory. But these guys are also going through a 12-Step program -- "Fish are friends, not food " -- adding a wacky hilarity (when one of them goes for Marlin, the other two rush to block, crying out "Intervention! "). One of the movie's funniest bits is also one of its most dazzling, as Marlin and Dory encounter a school of fish who, as a collective, are adept at impersonations. Finding Nemo keeps the excitement quotient on high -- sometimes a little too high, as the action gets to be dizzying in spots. And the narrative transitions between the ocean and the dentist's office are structurally awkward.

The film possesses a luster and beauty never before seen in an animated film, computer or otherwise. The refraction of light, the gentle, cresting wave of sea anemones, the constant flutter of fish, sets up a background environment that is constantly in motion. The computing power alone needed to render this kind of realism is staggering. Finding Nemo lures you into its world, to the point where you feel almost as though you are floating under the sea. It's a remarkable achievement, a perfect pairing of genuine artistry with technology.

Stanton and co-director Lee Unkrich coax stunning vocal performances out of an A-List cast. Albert Brooks, one of my own personal favorites, gives an anything-but-floundering performance as Marlin, the consummate neurotic-yet-loving parent. But it's DeGeneres who steals every frame of film as Dory, who, in an inspired touch, has no short-term memory. And you will not soon forget the brilliantly funny sequence in which Dory attempts to communicate with a whale. DeGeneres transcends the character's surface humor and winds up providing the film's most poignant, heartfelt performance. If there were an Oscar for best portrayal of a tropical fish, our Ellen would win by more than a fin.

Title: Grade A Quality
Review:
I'm always consistently amazed at what Pixar is able to do. With each passing film, they improve their craft again and again, transporting us to worlds where toys talk, insects can make inventions, and where monsters live and work just like we do. With their latest release, "Finding Nemo," I am reminded once again why I love going to the movies.

The environment of the film is painfully detailed and realistic. My favorite example occurs in the salt-water fish tank that Nemo is being held in. In order to escape, the fish have to sabotage the tank. When they do sabotage it, the tank begins to get dirty instantly. If you've ever had a salt-water tank, you know that as soon as the little bubble thing stops working, the grim begins to gather and start forming in the tank almost instantly. It's such a great touch.

Two of my favorite scenes involved the jellyfish forest and the inside of the whale. Marlin and Dory have to race through a jellyfish forest. All around are these pink orbs with tentacles and the animation is sharp and quick. It is a heart racing sequence that I honestly feel had the same excitement level of the car chase scene in "The Matrix Reloaded." The whale scene is just beautifully detailed, particularly on the whale's tongue. I honestly thought it was a real tongue.

Speaking of real, Pixar has the incredible ability to cause you to forget that toys, insects, monsters, and now fish aren't actually human. They talk just like humans do ("What is with men and asking for directions?"). A standout scene occurs when Marlin has given up and saving Nemo and is ready to abandon Dory and go back to the reef. Dory gives an impassioned, demonstrative plea to not give up and keep her on as a friend, something that she sees Marlin desperately needs. The scene does not at all feel out place in this tightly paced film.

The reason this film works is because these fish seem human and because the fish display their voice's owners great. Even if you've just seen the previews for "The In-Laws," you can see that Albert Brooks has experience playing the nervous, frantic, neurotic worrywart. Marlin's facial expressions even resemble a few of Brooks'. Dafoe's Gill is edgy, but has a hint of quiet desperation lined with hope of getting back to his home waters and out of that awful tank. But the real scene stealer is DeGeneres as Dory. Scatterbrained, peppy, light-hearted, and caring with an obvious intelligence, Dory is simply the core of the film. DeGeneres deserves an Oscar nomination for such a fine performance.

Title: Home Alone with Fish
Review:
First off: the animation work is excellent. From a technical perspective this is a fine movie. It also has a few truly funny moments (sharks) and fairly decent voice-acting..

But this movie is terribly reminiscent of half the sitcoms and children's movies out there. It is like a cross-section of California stereotypes were given plastic surgery and dropped in water. The formula has been been tortured to death by Hollywood in general and Disney in particular.

Thus, Finding Nemo makes good watching for young children and people who don't see many films, but movie-lovers will find it boring and stale.

On the whole not a bad movie, but hardly an original piece of work: 3/5..

Title: an instant classic
Review:
A remarkable movie. One of the best animated movie of all time. It has great characters, a load of funny dialogue, and artistic images that only Pixar can create. It's a story of an overprotective father, doing his duty as a single parent for his only son, Nemo. The father, named Marlin, went panic when Nemo got caught by some divers. So, began the journey of finding his son, Nemo (who's now in the aquarium with other fish). Marlin met a forgotful fish named Dory who helped him in finding his son. On the other hand, Nemo and the aquarium gank desperately wanted to get out from the aquarium. This story is full of message, that parents should be more trustful to their children. That teamwork can solve your problems. That, even if you're a handicapped person, doesn't mean that you can't do anything. Doesn't mean that you have to be protected. It's a family entertainment with heavy message. It's an animated feature at it's most amazing graphics. You'll actually feel wet while watching this movie. It's like you are one of the fish in the computer generated ocean.

Finding Nemo takes animation technique further than what Toy Story did. You just have to see it to believe it. What I love the most about this movie is the richness of it's characters. You'll immediately love Marlin, Dory, Nemo and other characters in this picture. Because they are so real. So funny. So memorable. Finding Nemo has a big strenght in comedy too. Just hear the dialogue and get ready to laugh out loud. There's plenty of jokes here. The clownfish who isn't funny. Sharks who don't eat fish. A pelican who befriend with fish. Sea turtles who talks like surfers. As Pixar said, you just gotta sea it. Sea it. It's better than any of the recent Disney films. It's a treasure, and shares a room with Beauty and The Beast, Lion King, Aladdin and others as the best family entertainment of all time. See it, you won't be disappointed, you'll love it, you'll thank me for that, and you'll know that I'm not lying. 9/10

Title: Not Just a Kid's Movie
Review:
It seems as though rated "G" movies are often under-advertised and never really make money or are even worth watching. Generally they're made specifically for children and any humor in the movie is lost on those over the age of seven. Pixar, in the past, has defied these common sentiments with movies like Toy Story 1, Toy Story 2, A Bug's Life, and Monster's Inc. Pixar continues to defy standard Hollywood practices with the release of Finding Nemo.

This movie is, by at least a little bit, the best rated G movie I've ever seen. Monster's Inc comes in a little behind in second place. The animation in this movie is incredible, the water, the fish, the particles of dirt floating in the water...there were many points when I would watch the movie and could definitely not be sure whether I was looking at a real or animated sea-scape.

The story...the story wasn't anything particularly groundbreaking other than the setting...father loses his son, will do anything to find him. In this case, anything includes taking on sharks, jellyfish, pelicans and other random sea monsters. The father, Marlin, is a clownfish that defies his name by being particularly unfunny...luckily he picks up a sidekick early on with a short term memory problem - a little memento-esque.

Nemo, the son, is captured by divers and put in an aquarium in Australia, where he meets several psychotic fish including "Gills," another fish from the open sea - whose voice belongs to William Dafoe (in a non-bad guy role!).

Of course, being a comedy, the movie does have a happy ending, but the ending isn't nearly as much fun as the trip taken to get there. The movie is great, I went along with two college age friends, and they both laughed as much as I did. If a kid's movie can make three college students laugh as hard as we did...it is definitely worthwhile seeing. The movie is genuinely funny and worth watching with the entire family. The movie is safe for small children, though there are a couple of potentially scary scenes that might frighten *really* young children. However, I would definitely recommend going to a later showing...after most children would be in bed. I made the mistake of watching "Ice Age" at 5 PM - and the theater was unfortunately filled the the laughter/screams/crying of children, which took a little away from the movie for me.

One more thing - Pixar shares a short 3-5 minute computer animated short. In fact, it was the first short ever created by Pixar. The short was also very humorous and just made the whole movie experience more enjoyable. There was also a preview for Pixar's upcoming movie: "The Incredibles" which seems to be about a dysfunctional family of aging superheroes which I can only assume will be just as enjoyable and amusing as "Nemo."

Title: Grab Shell for the ride of your life!
Review: If you haven't seen this movie get down to the cinema before you miss out on the best film of all time! It is without a doubt the sweetest, funniest, most exciting film I (and many others) have seen in years! The backgrounds are beautiful and so life-like! And I can barely find words to describe the characters. They are superbly animated and are brought to life by some extremly talented actors. If (and I very much doubt it) you aren't sure of the plot, here's an insight to it: After the death of his wife and 399 children, Marlin the Clownfish becomes over-protective of his only surviving son, Nemo. When Nemo gets tired of his fathers protectiveness, he abandons the safety of his home and ends up being captured by an Austrailian diver. Nemo then finds himself in the company of the 'Tank Gang' in a dentists office tank. Meanwhile, Marlin desperatly tries to find his son, with the help of the memory-losing, optimistic and Danger-Prone Dory, a Regal Blue Tang fish. Together they encouter vegitarian sharks, a forest of Jellyfish, the EAC-surfing turtles and many more colourful characters in this story about the seas most dedicated father, Marlin and the funniest fish in the world, Dory. I am positive that any Disney-Pixar, fish or touching-movie fan will not be able to resist the brilliance of this film. Treat yourself to Disney-Pixars Greatest acheivement, Finding Nemo! 10/10! Jenny xxx

Title: Awesome!
Review:
This has to be one of the best animated movies ever! It was funny, exiting, well animated, and suitable for all age groups (well, really young ones might find it a bit scary). The animation was unbelievable - there were scenes that could have been straight out of a photograph, if things weren't moving in it. Of course, the characters don't look that realistic, but they are still very well animated, I was impressed as usual by Pixar's talent. I thought the acting was great, the characters were very well done, and the dentist scenes were just funny beyond belief. And the sea turtles. I usually don't like Disney movies, but this one takes the cake.

Title: I LOVED IT!!!
Review:
OK, I am thirteen years old. I had no intention of seeing Finding Nemo. However, my little sister decided that she wanted to and asked if I wanted to go too. I probably wouldn't have gone, except that the last two Disney movies I had seen (Monsters Inc. and Lilo & Stitch) had actually been pretty good. Those I had seen on DVD, so this time I decided to see it in theatres.

Let me tell you, I am SOOOOO glad I went! The animation was AWESOME- I have never seen water portrayed so realistically in an animated film before. The storyline was great too, not so many sad moments that it killed the film but not so many funny parts that half the movie was completely pointless to the plot. Plus, you've got your suspenseful OMG-a-shark-is-chasing-me scene, gotta love that. The characters were fun to watch but not too cutesy, as I had expected a Disney/Pixar movie about fish to be.

All I have to add is, Finding Nemo has officially beat Monsters, Inc. as my favorite Disney movie. I am soooo going to get it on DVD Go see it soon!

Title: ABSOLUTELY BRILLIANT MOVIE!!!!!
Review: going along with all the other reviews, all I can say is WOW!!! Pixar/Disney has a MASTERPIECE here. We do not go to the movies very often because of the prices nowadays (looking at around 30-35 bucks for a family of 3- refreshments included). So when we go, We are very picky about the movies we see. my wife and son wanted to see Nemo. I was wanting to see something else. I gave in and wasn't expecting much. cmon it's a kids movie. Boy, was I WRONG!!! This is by far the best movie we've watched in years. I was completely impressed. The visuals are outstanding and the characters different personalities are great. The movie kept my son (4) attentive throughout (something that hasn't happened much). Usually it's the "dad i need a drink, dad i gotta go to the bathroom, dad I want my toys". Not this one. And I think it relates to kids and adults alike. Very funny and has subtle messages. 1.Nemo taking his disability in stride. 2.Parents have to let their kids grow up and explore. This movie hit home several times. Even though I hate to admit it, I actually got a little choked up when Marlin and Nemo finally got back together. That's how involved in the film you'll get. Do Not Let the chance to see Finding Nemo pass you by. Trust me, you'll love it. Money very well spent. We're going back to watch it again this weekend. and will DEFINITELY add this one to the DVD collection when its released. ABSOLUTELY Five stars!!!!!!!! 5/5

Title: Amazing
Review:
(give aways... if not seen movie, do not read b/c i say stuff from movie)

hey! I think this is an amazing movie. It is sooo adorable. I love the way they did animation with the water and everything. These actors put so much into this work, as you can see, they made it work. It just shows in the production. I cried.. lol go figure. It just got me so touchy at the beginning... how after there were all those eggs, that stupid shark ate them all, and coral.. ohhh my poooor coral. i felt soo bad for marlin. Nemo was the last one who survived so obviously you'd guess that marlin would be cautious for his only baby. Then when nemo got caught by those divers... grrr i'm seriously never going fishing again i felt so bad after all those times i go fishing and awwww poor nemo gets stuck in a DENTIST'S OFFICE! poor poor nemo. My favorite character was probably crush, the turtle. and I thought that was soo cute with the whole "how old did a turtle get" with nemo and his dad. I also liked dory... I really had a feeling that dory and marlin were gonna hook up or something, but i guess marlin just wasn't "attracted" to this short-termed memory fish. And i thought that was sooo funny how she remembered everything after nemo said something to her towards the end and then they found marlin, then dory needed help.. geeze these characters got into a lot of mischief! My favorite scene was probably with the whole "talking whale." after all that with dory, and then marlin trying to talk whale "gee i wish i could talk whale" lol. Well to wrap this up, i'd like to ask a question.. after Gill and all them escaped from the denists office.. how the hell did they get out of the bags? i saw this with my boyfriend and when gill proposed his idea thats the first thing i said "how are they gonna get out of the bags?" It's like, impossible for them to. They'd die! awww poor gill... his dream... well thats all i'm gonna say. I just have to say that i loved this movie. It made me laugh, and it made me cry. well.. ok then.. bye

Title: Great animation, great characters, great movie indeed.
Review:
I'll be totally honest and confirm to you that everything what they say about this movie is true. It's a brilliantly animated masterpiece with lots of humor that actually works and a plot that really brings tears to your eyes from time to time. The modern artists of Pixar never cease to amaze the audience in expanding their horizons. Finding Nemo is visually stunning and you can have nothing but respect for the people who created it.

I was more or less skeptic about watching it, because it was so overhyped ! Two days before it got released in my country, the TV and press loudly announced that the DVD broke all records in the USA during its first release-day. That's usually a sign of being typically mainstream and fake...but Finding Nemo is not. I'm allergic to fake sentiment and pathetic feel-good movies but I was really touched by this one. The moral and valuable life lessons are always present, but they're not shoved down your throat or thrown in your face all the time. This movie really relativates itself and that's important for a good comedy. And it's hilarious !!! Every side character in Finding Nemo (and there are a LOT of them) is exceptional and worth a mention. And the voices are cast perfectly as well...like the voice of Willem Dafoe for Gill, for example...a perfect choice. The character of Dory ( speaks through the voice of Ellen DeGeneres ) steals the show. She's an adorable blue fish who suffers from amnesia. She forgets what she's doing or going to every five minutes and that really leads to hilarious situations.

Movies like this aren't just being made for children exclusive... They're good for everyone to realize you have to entertain yourself from time to time and just to enjoy the little things in life. I recommend this to everyone in the world. No matter if you're 9 or 99 years old, Finding Nemo will bring a smile on your face and leave behind a warm feeling in your heart.

I think this movie is the best movie i've seen in the whole year. I really like the animation and the story.. even though a lot of people said it's for kids but i think there something deep and meaningful about the whole thing. I love the character Dory.. so funny.. Anyway I think it's a very good family movie like other Pixar movie. I love it so much that i can say that people who said that it's a stupid pointless movie are stupid themselves.

Title: Amazing!
Review:

Title: Adventurous, fun, emotional and narratively perfect.
Review:
When I was younger, and I watched this movie numerous times, I understood that it was one of those few animated films that made me feel immersed in an adventurous world, full of characteristics close to human. All this through a story of ... FISH.

That, ladies and gentlemen, is difficult to achieve in any story, and to date, after almost 15 years, the film still has the same effect on me.

Thanks to this epic family drama, I was able to approach the work of greats like Pixar, the ingenious Thomas Newman, the fascinating and inspiring Lee Unkrich, and why not, a John Lasseter and an Andrew Stanton and a huge team of talented people. People who are able to bring stories with little appeal to great stories that are stored in the permanent mind of thousands of people.

There is no doubt that visual beauty is not far behind. In fact, that is what makes the film even more attractive, and to this day, it still looks impressive, even with all the great technological advances that exist in the animation and technology film industry.

Undoubtedly, Finding Nemo, will go to the cult cinema in the very near future as did Toy Story.

Title: best animated film i have ever seen
Review:
An animated film, on the life in the ocean. This was the film I was waiting for. Hats off to Pixar studio, for making such an amazing film. They explored a whole lot of space left in the world the ocean. An also a story about a father who is in search of his son, it sounds a little schmaltzy, but you will love this emotion when you watch the film Marlin is the father who is in search of his son Nemo. His son is trapped by the fishermen and is now in an aquarium in a dentist's room.

All the characters in the fish tank were amazing The most amazing fish (character) was Dory who helps Marlin in finding her son. And the fun part is that she has a short term memory loss. This added the funny flavor to the film. And the sharks who take an oath that they will never eat a fish were the funniest of them all. This film is for everybody in the family. I rate this film 9/10

Title: This movie really blows everything out of the water!
Review:
This Pixar film, I believe, really gone and done it. I truly think they made a 101% job on Finding Nemo. It's funny for all ages, it's emotional, the morals spill out plain to see, it's adventurous, the film is top notch state of the art, and it's original. It really inspired me, and I've been coming up with stories all my life. I never thought to create a story about fish parenting in the ocean. I personally think it's so good that all animation movies should be compared to Finding Nemo before and after release. It was a top box hit, and full of extras as well. Pixar is really reeling in the cash. It was a jackpot of a film, and it will be extremely hard to make another film that will size up to it or even beat Finding Nemo. Of course with tomorrows technology I could see that happening in the next few years. Go see it if for some reason you haven't already.

Title: Not quite Monsters Inc. but entertaining nonetheless

Title: Truly a gem!
Review:
Since it was hard to imagine Pixar ever topping its original Toy Story, and upon first learning on who was going to provide the voices of the characters, I was not enthusiastic about Finding Nemo. None of the other Pixar releases (Bug's Life, Toy Story 2, Monsters Inc.) quite measured up to the original Toy Story, so I had reduced Nemo to rental status. It took a sold out show of Pirates of the Caribbean to make me experience one of the most enjoyable movies I have had the pleasure of watching on the big screen. There are movies that can be enjoyed equally on the theaters or at home, and there are others that you just have to shell out the 8 or so dollars and watch it on theater, and Finding Nemo is definitely one of the latter.

The computer recreation of water and light should in itself amaze you. I know it did to me. The way sand floats, how light shines through rippling water, how algae looks in a dirty aquarium...all recreated in a way that exceeded any expectations I may have had. The story, albeit simplistic in form, is touching and quick paced. The movie never feels like it is an hour and forty minutes long, and that is because Nemo has what I consider one of the best voiced over animated character ever in movie cinema. Never in my wildest dreams would I have thought that Ellen DeGeneres, whom I never cared for as an actor, could match, and even toppled Woody Allen's comedic delivery as Z in ANTZ, but she delivers the goods, and then some. As the voice of the memory lacking Dory, DeGeneres performance is truly worthy of recognition. Add the amazing way the animators converted DeGeneres excellent voice performance into animated facial expression on Dory, and you have one exquisite character. She is truly the highlight of the film.

Funny, addictive, surprising, mesmerizing, Finding Nemo has the substance to please both young and old alike. Just be sure you experience Nemo on a theater...you will be sorry if you don't.

Title: 10 Stars. More clever than Toy Story & Monsters, Inc.
Review:
Played to a packed Saturday matinee. Audience applauded at end. Clever, fun and entertaining, with few slow spots in the plot, our adults and kids enjoyed Finding Nemo very much. We guessed that Disney/Pixar was going to release this in Early December 2003 for Christmas Video/DVD sales - and it will be one of the hottest gift items for Xmas 2003.

Roger Ebert review is very accurate, and I would classify Nemo as a "must see" type of movie.

Movies like this aren't just being made for children exclusive... They're good for everyone to realize you have to entertain yourself from time to time and just to enjoy the little things in life. I recommend this to everyone in the world. No matter if you're 9 or 99 years old, Finding Nemo will bring a smile on your face and leave behind a warm feeling in your heart.

Title: Another world (and, finally, the movie that gets us there)
Review:
I think that some of the more recent box-office successes have been attractive because they have been able to transport people out of this hectic world into some other place. These movies, such as the original Star Wars Trilogy, the first Matrix movie, The Lord of the Rings, and others, have created this escape in enough depth and detail such that the viewer feels fully removed from their actual surroundings.

Only a handful of these movies though, can take the audience somewhere else and still deal with real-world issues, all at once. Finding Nemo is one of these movies. And believe me, this "other world" is like nothing you've ever seen on the big screen.

Pixar has out-done everyone, INCLUDING themselves. Finding Nemo's underwater world is on the one hand distant and mysterious and on the other distinguishable and realistic. The ocean setting has allowed Pixar to really let loose -- with amazing canvases of brilliant color, a shimmering, shifting, particulate-filled sea, and some of the best drawn non-human characters ever. In Finding Nemo there is a wonderful paradox: a far-away world that you can actually visit when you leave the theater.

But Finding Nemo's fantasy and reality two-step doesn't stop with the animation. The story takes that same theme. The characters -- a family of clown fish, a blue tang, a posse of sharks, pelicans, crazy seagulls, and the demonic dentist's daughter -- add a sense of fantasy and humor. But their trials -- the young one finding himself, a father's struggle against loss, the lonely one's sense of need, and the elder's desire to break free from his trapped life -- are real-world, everyday issues. And, in typical Disney fashion, the movie is moved along by an epic quest that brings all of these disparate pieces together. Everything in Finding Nemo is allegorical, and although the story line itself is not as creative as some show-stopping narrative like Requiem for a Dream, the way the script relates to both the characters at the fantasy level and the audience at the reality level is novel and inspiring.

Despite some of my roommates' skepticism, I wanted to see this movie from the moment I first heard the concept. For me -- that's some hype to live up to. But unlike the sequels in the Matrix and Star Wars series, Finding Nemo delivers -- a fantasy / reality combination that I hope won't soon be forgotten. 10/10

Title: Worth the wait!!
Review:
Disney didn't seem to be delivering the goods like they used to until Nemo came along and boy was he worth the wait. I never thought the clown fish can be so sweet. Finding Nemo is a great family film enjoyed by all. When watching it you'll find that at least two people will come out trying to speak whale or quoting 'Fish are friend, not Food' but that's what makes the film so great and memorable. If you have not seen the film yet - Where have you been? You'll fall completely in love with all of the characters and insist that you buy your own aquarium for your own Nemo cast. I hope that Disney's next project is a good as 'Finding Nemo' - Good Luck.

Title: Disney Orphans
Review:
First of all, I loved this movie. Thought everything was well designed and freakin' hilarious. It did lead me to an observation that I find intriguing. Why is it that probably 90% of Disney movies center on characters who are either orphans or have lost one or the other of their parents? Think about it. Name 5 disney movies, and I mean originals (non of those crappy sequels), that have characters with both of their parents. It's tough isn't it? Why does Disney do this? Does it help audiences sympathize with the characters more? I don't know. If I was a parent I might be concerned for my kids. Watching these movies might lead them to believe that their parents are going to die and leave them in the uncapable hands of evil step mothers or something like that. I understand that many families today consist of single parent homes, but many of these movies have scenes or alude to the death of one or both parents. I don't know if anyone has some insight into why this is, but I find it interesting.

Title: Masterpiece
Review:
It's been seven years since Pixar unleashed Toy Story 2, the first full-length computer animated feature film, on the world, and what a wild, whimsical ride it was. Working in tandem with Disney (an association perilously close to ending), Pixar has provided several equally wondrous rides -- Toy Story 2, A Bug's Life, Monsters Inc., all of which contained themes and characters perfectly suited to the hyper-realistic computer-generated style of animation. Pixar's films feature carefully crafted narratives, simple but not simplistic, offering an ebb and flow of action-stoked set pieces that, at best, stoke our adrenaline while keeping our funny bones on vibrating overdrive.

For it's 2003 release -- and perhaps greatest -- achievement, Pixar looks into the majestic depths of the ocean. The result -- Finding Nemo -- is a movie of extraordinary visual spectacle, astonishing emotional depth, and brilliant voice acting (Ellen deserved an Oscar nomination). It's every bit as inventive as the Toy Story franchise, every bit as charming as Bug's Life, every bit as colorful and vibrant as Monster's Inc. But it's even more compelling, more emotionally driven than these precursors. Everything, in a sense, has led up to Nemo, the best of all possible computer animated worlds.

Title: The Best Animated Film of All Time
Review:
This 2003 triumph from Pixar - the outfit that gave us both "Toy Story" movies and "MonSters, Inc." - has a more emotionally substantial story than its predecessors, set against stunningly beautiful backgrounds that set a new high-water mark in the digital art form, surpassing even "Shrek," produced by Pixar's arch-rivals at PDI. This film proves Pixar reigns as the finest storytellers in family film. To create a grand odyssey for two lovable underdogs, the Pixar team mixes playfulness, a deep love of film, and a visual beauty that is unmatched in the industry. This is not just a great animated movie Â– it is a superior film, period.

Title: The best Pixar film yet!
Review:
Yes, it was THAT good!

First off, the animation was superb. We are talking total immersion in this oceanic adventure. No pun intended. Okay, it was. But still.... The amount of detail to each individual fish, shark, whale, seagull, anemone and turtle is astounding. If not for the human-like facial expressions/exaggeration and characteristics you would almost think you were watching a National Geographic special. Only better! And the water! Of course you have to make it believable that you are watching a movie about being underwater...and they sell it. Very realistic and imaginative depiction of ocean life down to how the sunlight streams through the water.

Okay, the eye-candy out of the way (wow, animation never looked so good!) the voice-acting is fantastic! Albert Brooks as Marlin (Nemo's Dad), Ellen DeGeneres stealing the show as Dory (she was extremely funny), and of course other big names like Geoffrey Rush, and Willem Dafoe and even Eric Bana of soon-to-be HULK fame lent their voice talents to this grand story.

If you don't know the story by now, it's basically this: Nemo is a clown-fish that accidentally ends up being taken from his home. Marlin, his over-protective father sets off to search for him in the big blue, and along the way picks up help from very interesting characters along the way, not the least of which is Dory.

During the first 15 minutes of the film you are introduced of course to the characters and then a tragedy occurs leading us to the events of having to find Nemo. Even though this film like all Disney fare, is intended for kids enjoyment, it has some grown-up themes and plenty of things for adults to enjoy. Pixar has demonstrated their ability to make a film on kids and adults level alike with their other efforts.

I was surprised but how successful and seamless a story this was, considering that it was director Andrew Stanton's first time at the helm of a Pixar studio's film... but he has carried the tradition of perfection with flying colors. Most movies, animated and non-animated alike, usually never get it so right.

The music is a superb mixture of orchestral music and appropriate tropical instrumental music to set the mood and tone of the story and it's various moments. Instead of Pixar favorite Randy Newman doing the score for yet another Pixar flick, the reins were handed to Thomas Newman, who is none other than Randy's cousin as well as the son of Alfred Newman, who is famous in his own right for his film scores before his death in 1970 resulting from emphysema. His (Alfred) most recognized work, and perhaps most insignificant, is the theme you hear during the FOX 20th Century studio trailers before one of their movies. At any rate, Thomas Newman has composed a fantastic score that sets the mood wonderfully, and yet never really stands out above the events of the movie. And why should it? The rendered animation is a sight to behold and carries the story well enough on it's own along with the stellar voice cast.

I give this movie 10 stars!

Title: Over rated
Review: First of all, let me tell you that I am not someone who just hates all animated movies. Infact I love The Lion King, and recently the only good Disney animated movies are the one's Pixar has made, so I have nothing against Pixar. Both Toy Story and Toy Story 2 are great movies,(especially the first one), and A Bug's Life and Monsters Inc. are definitly a cut above the modern animated movie, but I have to say with disappointment that Finding Nemo is not anywhere near those good movies. Let me start with my biggest complaint, TOO MUCH ACTION! This movie had way too much action for an animated movie. Animated movies aren't about action, but I guess the filmmakers of this movie didn't know that. While I don't mind some action sequences in an animated movie,( like the antalope stampede in Lion King), the action sequences in this movie get a little redundent. I guess the animators are tring to "wow" you with the animation, and maybe that would of worked if this was the first movie of it's kind, but now that a lot of these type of movies have come out it's just boring. So then you may ask, what are animated movies about? Two things, laughter and fun, which this film is lacking in. While the other Pixar movies have fun jokes for kids and intelligent jokes for adults this film has none. Sure there maybe a few smart jokes about aquatic creatures in the beginning, but most of the time there is an oppertunity for a joke, they start an action sequence. In my opion, Finding Nemo is probably the most over rated animated movie of all-time.

Title: Remarkable Film
Review: Finding new life in the old fish-story, Finding Nemo is another fine computer animated offering from the people at Pixar, just as family-oriented as their last offerings, and just as adventure and humor-filled as ever. The animation and backgrounds are superb; it's often a remarkable achievement, and the colorful scenes of marine life and reefs makes it a visual treat. Though the film takes a little while to get going, after a truly heart-wrenching tragic beginning (at least for an animated film), once the search for Nemo starts, it's a non-stop quest with one clever thing after another. In fact, much like its previous siblings, the script is full of amusing situations (such as the chaotic climax at the dentist's office), clever dialogue, and humorous finds. It's also packed to the gills (pun intended) with eccentric characters, such as a trio of sharks trying to kick the habit of eating other fish, a pack of surfer-dude sea turtles, and some dim-witted birds. But the funniest bits are, of course, the myriad of dangers the poor fish must face, from a sea of jellyfish, to the threat of predators, to being swallowed up by a whale. The voice actors, from the neurotic Brooks to the spacey DeGeneres, are all terrific, and well chosen.

Title: A favorite childhood movie
Review:
I was a big Finding Nemo fan. I should watch it again as an adult, but almost 20 years ago I was in love with this movie and watched it multiple times!

Nemo had a loving father, which I didn't. And I always wanted a relationship with my father. Seeing them separated made it almost traumatic for me! I was praying for them to reunite the entire film! The way they captured the world under the sea was fantastic! The facts were so accurate and they taught children in a creative way! Seeing the passion nemos father possessed was inspiring in many ways. He didn't quit, and love took him a long way. I will never forget this movie. Its a life long classic in my opinion!
