Title: Best Pixar movie!
Review:
I'll be totally honest and confirm to you that everything what they say about this movie is true. It's a brilliantly animated masterpiece with lots of humor that actually works and a plot that really brings tears to your eyes from time to time. The modern artists of Pixar never cease to amaze the audience in expanding their horizons. Finding Nemo is visually stunning and you can have nothing but respect for the people who created it.

I was more or less skeptic about watching it, because it was so overhyped ! Two days before it got released in my country, the TV and press loudly announced that the DVD broke all records in the USA during its first release-day. That's usually a sign of being typically mainstream and fake...but Finding Nemo is not. I'm allergic to fake sentiment and pathetic feel-good movies but I was really touched by this one. The moral and valuable life lessons are always present, but they're not shoved down your throat or thrown in your face all the time. This movie really relativates itself and that's important for a good comedy. And it's hilarious !!! Every side character in Finding Nemo (and there are a LOT of them) is exceptional and worth a mention. And the voices are cast perfectly as well...like the voice of Willem Dafoe for Gill, for example...a perfect choice. The character of Dory ( speaks through the voice of Ellen DeGeneres ) steals the show. She's an adorable blue fish who suffers from amnesia. She forgets what she's doing or going to every five minutes and that really leads to hilarious situations.

Movies like this aren't just being made for children exclusive... They're good for everyone to realize you have to entertain yourself from time to time and just to enjoy the little things in life. I recommend this to everyone in the world. No matter if you're 9 or 99 years old, Finding Nemo will bring a smile on your face and leave behind a warm feeling in your heart.

Title: Totally Awesome, dude!
Review:
Oh, my were do I begin, (smile), it was great. Nemo is fun to be with and you feel like a kid again. when you are really 30 something. ehehe well see it to believe, Pixar seems not to do wrong. OH, find Nemo in Monster Inc. somewhere? He's there, dude!

Title: Heartwarming and beautifully animated, Finding Nemo is one of the best movies out there
Review:
Finding Nemo is, as far as I know, the first animated movie that has real value for adults as well as kids. And not in the way that most kid films do, that are merely bearable and faintly amusing at best to anyone above the age of 14. Finding Nemo has a couple of essentials for all age groups: for kids, there is the moral of the story, the cute and funny characters (think the albatros and the turtle), and of course the happy ending. For adolescents and grown-ups, there are contemporary movie references, and more 'grown-up' jokes that might be hard to grasp for little kids. The amazing animation is always a huge added bonus for anyone who really pays attention to the movie, and would be worth going to the movies for even if the story was only so-so and the dialogue boring.

I know this whole age-group thing because after finally convincing my cousins, who are both boys (ages 10 and 12), to go with me, they watched it and actually enjoyed it. So did a very large part of people my age (16) and my parents have actually seen it twice.

Finding Nemo is a truly great move, and perfect to watch when you don't want to see something complicated, but are more in the mood for something uplifting yet still with substance.

9/10

Title: How do they do it?
Review:
You tend to get bored on an airplane. Not on my flight! From Amsterdam to New York takes about eight hrs, and I wasn't bored for a single minute. Cause they had all these cool movies to watch! So I started with the Matrix; Reloaded (not so good), followed by Finding Nemo.

Those guys @ Pixar, how do they do it? They always seem to find a new angle and a complete different idea for their movies. For instance; Toy Story 2 was totaly different from TS1, although it features a lot of the same characters.

And now this; Finding Nemo...

I didnt really know what to expect; a fish searching for his lost son, who's been kidnapped by a dentist? But hey, its a Pixar movie, so its gotta be good, right?

And so it was! I couldn't get that smile of my face, because this movie is hilarious! Starting with the totally new characters, the crazy storyline, and still it has that great "Pixar-feel" to it. Bright, vibrant colours, great voice acting, and -wow- beautifully animated (if that is correct English).

This is another MustHave for my DVD collection!

Title: Beautiful animation and Ellen is hilarious
Review:
Finding Nemo is a beautiful work of art. Ellen DeGeneres as Dory is fantastic in this film. The first time I heard Ellen's comedy was a routine that was played on an airplane about bad milk. She has such an interesting, quirky way of looking at the world and the writers of Finding Nemo captured that perfectly in the Dory's character. The animation is gorgeous. The color of the water and the way it changes as the characters swim through it is beautiful. Director Andrew Stanton is hilarious as Crush. What a talented guy. This movie has a great message for parents on good child-rearing and about taking chances and living even when life gives you a a setback like a tiny flipper.

Title: Best film of the summer- maybe of the year....
Review:
I saw this movie and was totally blown away. The previews looked good, so I figured the movie would be decent. But I was not prepared at all for how incredibly the movie drew everyone in. When I saw it, it wasn't with an enormous amount of little kids, but with people of all ages- 3 to 75. The voice acting is some of the best ever- especially Ellen DeGeneres. The character of Dory was taken to a whole other level by the quality of Ellen's voice work- you couldn't help but laugh hysterically at almost everything she said. However, she also proved she could do more than just comedy- I don't know how anyone cannot get the slightest bit misty when she says "I look at you, and....and I'm home..." Other great voices by Albert Brooks (Marlin), Allison Janney (Peach), Willem Dafoe (Gil), Alexander Gould (Nemo) and Brad Garrett (Brother Blow) make this movie one of the funniest and feel good films I've seen in a long time. A shoo in for Best Animated Feature at the Oscars this year, and I can even see a nod for Best Picture.

Title: Best animated movie I have ever seen- definitely worth seeing for anyone
Review:
I don't usually see animated movies in the theater, and when I do, I never see them a second time, except on video. However, this was the first exception. This immediately became my favorite animated movie, and I actually decided to go back and see it a second time. None of my friends who I saw it with the first time wanted to go back so I went with some others who hadn't yet seen it.

As an 18-year-old, I know many kids my age pan animated movies as only for younger kids, and while this is true for many of them, there have been several that are good for anyone. One of the features I have noticed in Pixar movies (Monsters, Inc.; Toy Story; this) is that they direct the action towards younger kids, but add a number of lines that only an older audience will understand.

Finding Nemo was excellent all around. Technically, it was incredibly well made- with realistic fish-like movements and equally realistic human-like facial expressions, not to mention the amazing aquatic scenery. The technical part actually added to the movie as a whole, making the characters more real, and therefore easier to relate to, despite the fact that they were fish. And then, of course, the plot and action of the film were great. It was funny, creative, and simply entertaining in general. The characters were likeable, the action was fast-moving, and the story was well-written. This will easily win best animated feature of 2003.

In fact, the only criticism I have is not of the movie but of Pixar: since they did almost all the work in creating this film, it seems that they really don't need Disney as a distributor. They have already made enough of a name for themselves that without the backing of a giant motion-picture distributor, they could release the films themselves and produce the same amount of money- only they would be able to keep it all, instead of having to fork over huge portions to Disney.

Title: Pleasant, not exactly funny.
Review:
I thought the movie was pleasant--I got a couple of chuckles. I love the Toy Story movies, Shrek, Bug's Life, so with all the great reviews I was primed for a real laugher. I just didn't laugh, though. The whale talk got stale--fast, the 12 step shark program wasn't that funny. I liked the seagulls, and I liked the Psycho reference. Finally, I thought the most striking thing was that Marlin (the father) was the one expected to mature and let Nemo go. Yet, if Nemo had listened to his father in the first place, he wouldn't have had to be found.

Title: Disappointing.
Review:
I would estimate...about 97% of the movie going world loved this movie.

However, I did not. I'm aware young children have higher pitched voices, but the particular children for supporting roles in this movies had voices I thought were going to bore into my brain.

The story is simple. Nemo, a young fish who is the only survivor of his siblings is dared to go out into open water, and thus is captured. His overprotective father, who seems to have Nemo alone as remaining family, naturally, goes to look for him.

From there, we're introduced to supporting characters who I found weren't much more than cheap laughs. Vegetarian sharks, ooh, that's original! All in all, the plot seems pretty much inconsequential to beautiful sweeping shots of the ocean and the coral reefs the fish call home. The scene with the jelly fish I found quite a treat to look at...but other than being yet another piece of eye candy that seems to be a trend nowadays....this movie has very little to offer.

Title: Better than Monsters, Inc. ?
Review:
I was truly astounded by what I saw. The effects of the water and little background objects was amazing. On some levels it made Monsters, Inc. look ancient. The story was a typical "Have to find somebody" plot but it had a fresh take on it as the single parent made it more real. The thing that sets this movie apart from others is the secondary characters. Pixar really pays attention to getting these right. Sometimes they even overshadow the main characters they get to be so good. As always, lessons are learned and fun was had by all. After Jungle Book 2 and countless other run of the mill sequels Disney is pumping out, Pixar again shows that Disney needs lead or get out of the way. I generally rate a movie on the consumption of food. A lot of food eaten, it was bad. Hardly any food eaten, too good. So let's put it this way: My 6 year old sat transfixed and my 3 year old sat with his face on the seat in front of him watching. All the food consumed? 5 pieces of licorice. That's it. They were just far too busy watching to eat.

Title: Anti-American slam
Review:
Perhaps you missed. It was quick, but the message was there. The slam on Americans. When Marlin was telling the group of sharks that divers had taken Nemo, the response was "Humans, they think they own everything." Then the comment, "Yeah, must be Americans." Excuse me Disney, but that offends me. I am American and proud. Title: Absolutely stunning, a faultless piece of entertainment
Review:
This film is quite simply a work of genius. The quality of the animation is stunning, with the effects of waves, reflections, splashes, and underwater motion all perfectly realised. The visual treat is perfectly complemented by a brilliant script that is easy to follow for youngsters, while being full of droll asides and references to keep the adults amused. The idea that the sharks are in therapy to try and overcome their fish-eating tendencies, and the associated psycho-babble is one hilarious example. Another reviewer complained that the basic story is unoriginal, being yet another quest / journey of self-discovery. Well I think younger kids need a simple plotline, and this film delivers it so well that any triteness never jars. My daughter (nearly 5) was held in rapt attention throughout - and so were her mother and I. Highly recommended.

Title: Very good family film!
Review: This was one of the most successful Disney films at the cinema to date. It is the underwater story of a young clown fish named Nemo (Alexander Gould) taken by divers and put into a tank. The idea is obviously his Dad, Marlin (Albert Brooks), and new friend Dory (Ellen DeGeneres), who has short-term memory loss, are "finding" him. Meanwhile, Nemo along with new friends including fishes Gill (Willem Dafoe), Bloat (Brad Garrett), Peach (Allison Janney), Gurgle (Austin Pendleton), Bubbles (Stephen Root), Deb/Flo (Vicki Lewis), Jacques (Joe Ranft) and pelican Nigel (Geoffrey Rush) are trying to escape. Along the journey Marland and Dory encounter three sharks, including Bruce (Barry Humphries, aka Dame Edna Everage) (named after the rubber Shark in the Jaws series), stinging jellyfish, turtles in a current tunnel, including "dude" Crush (Andrew Stanton) and much more, but he finds him eventually, and everything's fine. Also starring Big's Elizabeth Perkins as Coral, Nicholas Bird as Squirt, Bob Peterson as Mr. Ray, Eric Bana as Anchor, and Toy Story's John Ratzenberger as Fish School. It won the Oscar for Best Animated Feature, and it was nominated for Best Music, Original Score for Thomas Newman, Best Sound Editing, and Best Writing, Original Screenplay, it was nominated the BAFTA for Best Original Screenplay, and it was nominated the Golden Globe for Best Motion Picture - Musical or Comedy. It was number 13 on The 100 Greatest Family Films.

Title: Very Good Movie
Review:
I'll be totally honest and confirm to you that everything what they say about this movie is true. It's a brilliantly animated masterpiece with lots of humor that actually works and a plot that really brings tears to your eyes from time to time. The modern artists of Pixar never cease to amaze the audience in expanding their horizons. Finding Nemo is visually stunning and you can have nothing but respect for the people who created it.

I was more or less skeptic about watching it, because it was so overhyped ! Two days before it got released in my country, the TV and press loudly announced that the DVD broke all records in the USA during its first release-day. That's usually a sign of being typically mainstream and fake...but Finding Nemo is not. I'm allergic to fake sentiment and pathetic feel-good movies but I was really touched by this one. The moral and valuable life lessons are always present, but they're not shoved down your throat or thrown in your face all the time. This movie really relativates itself and that's important for a good comedy. And it's hilarious !!! Every side character in Finding Nemo (and there are a LOT of them) is exceptional and worth a mention. And the voices are cast perfectly as well...like the voice of Willem Dafoe for Gill, for example...a perfect choice. The character of Dory ( speaks through the voice of Ellen DeGeneres ) steals the show. She's an adorable blue fish who suffers from amnesia. She forgets what she's doing or going to every five minutes and that really leads to hilarious situations.

Movies like this aren't just being made for children exclusive... They're good for everyone to realize you have to entertain yourself from time to time and just to enjoy the little things in life. I recommend this to everyone in the world. No matter if you're 9 or 99 years old, Finding Nemo will bring a smile on your face and leave behind a warm feeling in your heart.

Title: Animation at it's best
Review:
I would like to congratulate Pixar studio for this movie, especially because story is so weak and has almost nothing in it. All the other Pixar movies before this had superb stories and now the trick was how did they made it click even then?

One thing I have noticed that Pixar seem to have mastered the art of story telling. Realistic and state-of-the-art animation just add on to it. Good script is something that makes this movie work for every age group. I have seen it many times and found that some of these dialogs could still make me laugh.

I will not say this is the best Pixar movie but it is different and of course it is a visual treat. Dialogues are superb. Characters are well defined and you just fall in love with them. A must for all animation lovers.

Title: A "special ed" story
Review:
This is a great movie filled with beautiful visuals, wonderful voices, and a story that mimics life so heavily that I don't even think people can grasp it. Here you have Nemo, a fish who has a visible handicap (but not handicapping condition). His father, who lost his mate and whole brood (minus Nemo) wants to protect him with everything he has in him, yet Nemo just wants to be like everyone else and do what the other kids are doing. In the process of showing everyone what he can do by swimming further out over the drop than the other fish, he gets scooped up by a scuba diver and all of his father's nightmares come true: he's lost his only son.

The story goes on to show what a parent will do for their child. In his quest to find his child, he runs into other sea life who all have their own disabilities, not all visual, but are able to help him in their own way. Each one of these characters have something very special about them, be it something that helps or hinders their life. They are all living "normal" lives in the big blue world of the ocean. From one character with short term memory loss, others with obsessive-compulsive disorders, they all have a limitation but don't let it limit their life.

This movie punctuates how we think about physical differences and want to protect the people who have them yet everyone has some sort of difference, most of us who don't have it visible on our person. Each of us are able to accomplish great things, each of us have to overcome shortcomings in our lives and we all have some specialness, visible or not.

Title: Holds up 20 years later and always will
Review:
I remember watching Finding Nemo when I was around 9 years old. My parents made a huge deal of it and we watched it in the theater as soon as it released. It was an amazing theatrical experience and as a child it felt like a fantastical epic. Now 20 years later I have rewatched it at home and it has held up in every regard and was even more enjoyable the second time with a new perspective. The animated world they created is breathtakingly beautiful, the humor is great, and the story keeps you engaged without ever feeling repetitive or lackluster.

Finding Nemo will go down as a cultural and historic achievement and will be enjoyed for centuries to come. I can't wait to watch it with my future children and grandchildren.

Title: One of a Precious Few
Review:
As a 16 year old, i think of myself as still a child in many ways! My love of Disney Films being one of them. However, i find Finding Nemo is one of a dying breed... a Disney film which is actually good. OK, no matter what Disney films will always be here to delight children, but there are few Disney films being produced at the moment that seem to hold parents and children alike. Now it seems that a lot of the time Disney are just cashing in. EVERYTHING has a sequel! And none of the sequels are half as good as the original. I think the Pixar/Disney collaboration has been good. As i said, Finding Nemo is an amazing Disney film that has many of the memorable characters and witty lines that makes it a film sure to be remembered for years to come. I think Disney should stick to the new ideas for movies. New Stories. You don't need to make 7 Lion King movies or Aladdin movies for kids to still love the characters. The Land Before Time film from Universal was quite probably one of if not my favourite film when i was a kid. Now you look at Sky movies and they are showing Land Before Time IX and even more! So i say keep making stand alone films with the quality, care and thought that you put into Finding Nemo and you'll remain a success forever.

That's my two cents on that then! Hee hee x

Title: I loved it.
Review:
It was a very enjoyable experience. Lots of layers for all ages. Visually stunning.

Pixar has made many break throughs with each movie, with each having a quantum leap in something. The realistic water in Nemo is not quite as noticable as the leap of the fluffy/whispy fur in Monsters, but a big leap non the less.

I loved all the nice inside jokes and homages. I kept expecting a "Great Escape" homage with Gill, perhaps having his gimpy fin look like a ball glove or such, but I suppose some would have pointed out that Chicken Run already did it. I did think that Gill's scar looked a lot like the facial scar in Platoon (problem being it was Tom Berenger's character that had the scar not Defoe's), but then again I might have been looking for way too inside jokes (how about a West Wing hint with the Star fish).

I just about wet myself when she started trying to speak Whaaaallllle. I would have killed to have seen Ellen's face for real as she recorded those bits.

Title: Finding Nemo is a great family film!!!!
Review:
Finding Nemo is a great movie for not only kids, but parents will not mind watching it either. It's a great family film. Title: Disney's Pixar's Finding Nemo
Review:
How are you suppose to find someone you care about, when there are so many fish in the sea? This question can be answered in the kids film, Finding Nemo by Disney Pixar. This adventurous film takes place in the ocean where the main characters are fish. The film really shows family issues and how it affects children of adolescence in a funny kids animation about a real serious issue. The fathers and sons relationship starts out edgy because of the issues in the family, but the father and the sons relationship starts to grow throughout the film. In the end there's almost always a solution to this, but nothing you would quite see in the film, Finding Nemo. When the film is done and over, you will see how this can affect a child and how there can be misunderstandings to every action. But in the end there's only one truth.

The story starts out with the character Marlin and his wife, they are both clownfish. Marlin's wife dies by a tragic attack by a shark out in the open. His wife also laid a lot of eggs but after the shark attacked Marlin's wife, he took the eggs. There was only one left and this made the character Nemo, Marlin starts to get over protective with him because of what happened to his wife and the rest of his kids. But when Nemo starts to go to school he gets taken by divers. So Marlin sets out to find his son Nemo, he crosses by a fish named dory who suffers from short term memory loss. He goes with Dora and fights against many obstacles like sharks, jellyfish, and even seagulls. While nemo is trying to get out of a fish tank in a dentist's office.

Now this isn't the best film in the world, it has its bad sides. For instance this isn't really that accurate of a film. The start of the story line starts out with the mom dying and the dad still living with his son and now the father has nobody and he's lonely. But the truth if the same situation happened in real life, the father would have turned female and the son would have mated with the now turned female. Then nemo would have turned female and would have to find a male mate. But instead this isn't accurate, they use a human interactive way. This is only one of the major things that aren't accurate if this situation happened in real life. But of course this film is a adventure/action, fiction story.

I just want to say that this film is very interesting and has very many positive features in this film despite it not being very accurate to real life. There's so many lessons that kids can learn and also find it very entertaining at the same time. This film definitely shows family issues and how adolescents are affected by it. One way this is shown is by the father and sons relationship. In the film it shows right away at the beginning that the father doesn't want him to go to school while the son is insisting he goes on the first day, Nemo finally convinces his father to let him go. But the dad has to walk him there. This shows that the dad is very over protective over his son because he barely even allows him to go to his school. At some point in that scene he wouldn't even let nemo hangout with some people there. It really points out that there's family issues between the son and the father. Because nemo wants to go out and adventure while the father would just rather him stay safe and not go out. He wants this because he's afraid that he will lose his son if he isn't in his grasp. But all of that really connects with families with real issues like that because it can make them see all views and what's best to do about each situation. So it's a good learning experience in a great kids animation film.

Characters really are the main part of the film. If it wasn't for the characters, the film wouldn't be a film. But it's not just characters that are important in how the characters are, it's what their identity is. If a film had a bad characters then the film wouldn't be that good and it would be a bad film. For instance, in Finding Nemo there's a scene where when Nemo is trapped in the fish tank and a bird comes in the dentist's office window and talks to the fish in the fish tank. About a rumor going around that Marlin is trying to find his lost son. Nemo hears about it and gets excited because he believes he's gonna be saved. Because of the characters in this certain scene it makes people understand better, it makes the film the way it is. Because of the bird spreading around the rumor because he does that a lot, the bird loves gossip. Nemo was able to find out that his dad was going to save him which means the characters were a big role in the film. This showed Marlins and Nemos relationship clearly and how he felt about his dad. Because of the characters and even side characters it gave you a real feel to the film and really showed how this was effecting Nemo.

There's so much in this film, so many lessons hidden in the film through kids animation and child like characters. One of the main lessons was how a child of adolescents is affected by family issues. The way this is shown is by the characters and their development, and how it shows the father and sons relationship. The characters in the film are more child like and don't have anything that's inappropriate and even the animation is innocent. This and the father and son's relationship and what they say to each other shows how Nemo is affected and why he is the way he is. But in the end of the film it shows Marlin successfully getting his son back after almost failing and showing that he should never give up, and even saving Dora which he met on the way to find Nemo. There's a lesson on why you should never quit because if you don't you might even get what you want no matter how impossible it seems. But also it shows the father and sons relationship repaired and better than before. Because the family issues were resolved Nemo felt better and had a better life then with those family issues. This film was really great, it gave lessons for everyone on how you shouldn't quit and how a kid could be affected by family issues, and even how characters can be very important in a innocent animation.

Title: good movie
Review:
I just watched "Finding Nemo" with my two-year-old son. (He wasn't even born when this movie came out, which is why I've never seen it until today). I really liked this film for a number of reasons. Not only was it very intense emotionally, but there was no point in the film was anything *bad* happening. There were no cheap innuendos, nothing but good clean fun. At the same time, it was never stupid or clownish (no pun intended). I would really like the creators of this film to know that I appreciated their work as being an effort in "using one's powers for good, not evil." In addition, I'm sure that people who have similar dilemmas in their family life: children with special needs, parents who are overprotective, or anyone with a loss or grief in their family, will feel especially attuned to this film. This is a great movie for either families or individuals.

Title: Finding Nemo review
Review: Three years ago, Walt Disney Pictures and Pixar teamed up to release Finding Nemo to the masses. The hit children's underwater adventure video is an animated story based on a rebelliously independent young clownfish and his overprotective father's inability to let go. Enticed by a witty trailer and a captivating graphical design, Finding Nemo attracted a wide audience to the theatres. Digitally mastered and exquisitely written, Finding Nemo premiered May 3rd, 2003, as a G rated, light hearted, animated production geared towards children. The familiar voices of main characters, Dory (Ellen DeGeneres) and Marlin (Albert Brooks) teamed up in an encore partnership, returning from 1998's Dr. Dolittle. The hour and 44 minute presentation that brought over $300 million to the box office in its first week in the theatres. The script is a roller-coaster of friendly humor, written by Andrew Stanton and is sincerely thought provoking for Disney's adult viewers. Finding Nemo is sure to become a childhood classic. The opening scene is at Nemo's elementary school. Marlin, the widowed single parent, introduces Nemo to his teacher as a timid student, who requires extra attention for his special needs. Crowds will chuckle at the cynical humor, merciless mimicking students in the background and defining sarcastic gestures in this scene. Taunted by his peers, Nemo challenges his father, swimming farther and farther out into the abyss, towards a row boat at the surface. By the time Marlin catches his curiously disobedient son in the act, he swam far away from the group and was at the surface. The authors' creative expressiveness and ingenuity with the line "he touched the butt!" is innocent enough for six year olds to repeat, and at the same time harmlessly pokes fun at the daily trials parents face with young children. With the conscious lesson that every ill minded action has consequences, the row boat unexpectedly carries Nemo away from his home. Marlin enlists into a desperate rescue attempt for his beloved son and soon encounters Dory, the annoying travel companion with the funky problem of poor short term memory. In their travels, Marlin and Dory accidentally stumble upon two great white sharks. Instantly intrigued, Dory tries to make new friends, while Marlin backs off because of preconceived stereotypes about vicious great white sharks. As it turns out the two have joined to form an anti fish eating support group. With a membership pledge of "fish are friends, not food", Marlin and Dory escape a near death experience. In this fast paced scene that speaks to breaking stereotypes, adults will pick up on the parody on the politics of vegetarianism and a poke at "meaningless" support groups. Some of the content in this two minute scene may frighten younger viewers, as the loud noises, exploding mines and sharks with big scary teeth dominate the screen. Pressing on with the goal of finding his son in Sydney, Marlin and Dory ride the East Australian Current with a huge pack of sea turtles, and Marlin has a chance to tell his epic story. One of the elder turtles and an experienced parent, Crush (voice of Andrew Stanton) listens in, imparts some wisdom, and helps Marlin regain a firm a grasp on life. His advice, and the movie's main message, is that children are going to grow up and that part of successful parenting is letting them go and watching them. You have to know that you have done all you can for your children and that they have learned well. The climax of the movie is this scene, where Marlin realizes his error and finally begins to believe in his son. As the music tempo accelerates, the current quickens and the scene makes a dramatic switch back to a comedic tone, keeping children on the edge of their toes and leaving adults satisfied with the depth of content matter. Having arrived in Sydney, Marlin immediately jumps back into the search for his son. While the graphics change with the new on-land scenery, their impressive Pixar quality remains. New sounds from the city and music perfectly accompany every plot curve as the two fish face new challenges of human and bird interaction. A pelican named Nigel flies in to save the two fish from a particularly hungry flock of seagulls placing bids on their next meal, saying "Mine! Mine! Mine!" in their thick Australian brogue. The creative scripting is again paired with a hidden message of parenting that sometimes you need to take a risk and trust other people. Finding Nemo is a fantastic film, with much thought, enthusiasm and heart behind the plot, animation and message. Finding Nemo leaves Mom and Dad with a feeling of parental community in that they are not alone in their struggles with parenting. The innocent humor and narrative plot leaves children wanting to watch the movie several times over and quote their favorite lines with friends. The movie is appropriate for all children ages six and older and all adults who are young at heart. The underlying comedy and animation in this film hides a message that speaks of social issues, politics and parenting, which makes Finding Nemo a great movie for children and adults alike. Disney's Finding Nemo jumps a full step above Toy Story and does not even compare to the original classics like Cinderella, winning an Oscar Award and Best Animated Children's movie in the 2004 Academy Awards.

Title: Why...
Review:
I'll be totally honest and confirm to you that everything what they say about this movie is true. It's a brilliantly animated masterpiece with lots of humor that actually works and a plot that really brings tears to your eyes from time to time. The modern artists of Pixar never cease to amaze the audience in expanding their horizons. Finding Nemo is visually stunning and you can have nothing but respect for the people who created it.

I was more or less skeptic about watching it, because it was so overhyped ! Two days before it got released in my country, the TV and press loudly announced that the DVD broke all records in the USA during its first release-day. That's usually a sign of being typically mainstream and fake...but Finding Nemo is not. I'm allergic to fake sentiment and pathetic feel-good movies but I was really touched by this one. The moral and valuable life lessons are always present, but they're not shoved down your throat or thrown in your face all the time. This movie really relativates itself and that's important for a good comedy. And it's hilarious !!! Every side character in Finding Nemo (and there are a LOT of them) is exceptional and worth a mention. And the voices are cast perfectly as well...like the voice of Willem Dafoe for Gill, for example...a perfect choice. The character of Dory ( speaks through the voice of Ellen DeGeneres ) steals the show. She's an adorable blue fish who suffers from amnesia. She forgets what she's doing or going to every five minutes and that really leads to hilarious situations.

Movies like this aren't just being made for children exclusive... They're good for everyone to realize you have to entertain yourself from time to time and just to enjoy the little things in life. I recommend this to everyone in the world. No matter if you're 9 or 99 years old, Finding Nemo will bring a smile on your face and leave behind a warm feeling in your heart.

Title: Finding Nemo
Review:
"Finding Nemo" How many children love the ocean? The ocean is a fabulous place that holds many of our creatures in the world. Take an adventure with Nemo and his friends through the adventures, and dilemmas of the ocean. You will meet some fish whose home is in the ocean. What sounds like more fun then going on a rip tide ride with a sea turtle? Or meeting a shark who doesn't eat fish anymore? If you find the ocean one of the most fascinating places on earth then "Finding Nemo" is just the movie for you.

"Finding Nemo" came out in 2003, and caught many children's attention. The main characters are Nemo is who the little clown fish who is lost, Marlin who is also a clown fish, looking for his son Nemo, Dory who meets Marlin during his attempt to rescue Nemo. The movie is about a cartoon clown fish fish called Nemo, who wants to prove to his friends that he is not scared and gets taken away by a scuba diver, for a tank in a dentist office. Marlin who is Nemo's father tries to rescue Nemo during the whole movie. Marlin comes across new characters such as Dory, who becomes his partner in searching for Nemo. They go on an underwater adventure to save Nemo and come face to face with sharks, sea turtles, jellyfish, and so much more. It received 81/2 stars out of 10 on the rating scale for movies. It is 100 minutes long and won an Oscar for the making of this outstanding movie. The director of this movie Andrew Stanton and the Co-director is Lee Unkrich. The cartoon characters voices in this movie are done by famous people. Just some examples the voice of Nemo is Alexander Gould, the voice of Marlin is Albert Brooks and the voice of Dory is Ellen Degeneres.

This movie starts out at Nemo's coral reef home. His mother is killed in the beginning which sets the stage for his father taking care of him. Nemo goes to school on the first day. The class is taking a field trip to the drop off, which Marlin, Nemo's father is not happy about. Marlin goes to the drop off to save his son, but when he gets there he witnesses Nemo being taken away by a scuba diver. Nemo was proving to his friends that he can get the closest to a boat, and was kidnapped by a scuba diver for a dentist's fish tank at his office. Marlin decides to go on an adventure and look in the whole ocean to find Nemo. Marlin meets Dory, who is a forgetful, funny fish. She forgets things quickly, and she explains to Marlin she has short term memory. Dory decides to help Marlin find Nemo. They meet a shark called Bruce who is not eating fish anymore, they meet a sea turtle Squirt and go on a rip tide ride with the sea turtles towards where Nemo is, they come across a school of jellyfish, and a lantern fish. Nemo and Marlin come across many hardships during this movie. Now hopefully you are wondering does Marlin ever save Nemo? You will have to watch the movie and find out.

I think Marlin was a determined fish and father. During the whole movie he never once said he was going to give up. Partially I think what kept Marlin going was the fact that he lost his wife and now he doesn't want to loose his son. Marlin comes face to face with a shark Bruce, who brings him back to his other two friends that are sharks. They participate in an AA meeting against eating fish. Dory bumps her nose and starts to create blood this triggers Bruce and he then wants to eat fish. Marlin runs from the shark and never gives up. Even at the end when Marlin is safe he still continues to find Nemo despite what other hardships he will encounter. This shows a child who is watching "Finding Nemo" that it is not okay to give up. That when you want to achieve a goal such as Marlin wants to rescue Nemo you should continue you're hardest even when times get tough. This movie is targeted towards children at a young age, and I think it is important to teach them never to give up even when they are not succeeding. This movie, as well as Marlin the character gives a great example that you should never give up.

I thought this movie was an excellent movie for children. It teaches the children about the ocean and certain species that live in the ocean. It explains certain areas in the ocean such as a "drop off" or a "rip tide". The movie also teaches the children about these topics in a fun way. For example you go on a sea turtle ride down the rip tide. During the ride, the sea turtles are acting like they are surfing and the voices of the sea turtles change too. "Finding Nemo" also instills in young children to not give up. That you should continue to try when times get tough. In the beginning it also gives an example of why children should not go off on their own. It demonstrates that Nemo left his class and was taken away by someone that a child can relate to as a stranger. There are many lessons to be learned in the movie and they teach them in a creative way. That's why I think you should go watch "Finding Nemo" and take you kids along too. Then you can also find out if Marlin finds Nemo.

Title: a classic
Review:
I'll be totally honest and confirm to you that everything what they say about this movie is true. It's a brilliantly animated masterpiece with lots of humor that actually works and a plot that really brings tears to your eyes from time to time. The modern artists of Pixar never cease to amaze the audience in expanding their horizons. Finding Nemo is visually stunning and you can have nothing but respect for the people who created it.

I was more or less skeptic about watching it, because it was so overhyped ! Two days before it got released in my country, the TV and press loudly announced that the DVD broke all records in the USA during its first release-day. That's usually a sign of being typically mainstream and fake...but Finding Nemo is not. I'm allergic to fake sentiment and pathetic feel-good movies but I was really touched by this one. The moral and valuable life lessons are always present, but they're not shoved down your throat or thrown in your face all the time. This movie really relativates itself and that's important for a good comedy. And it's hilarious !!! Every side character in Finding Nemo (and there are a LOT of them) is exceptional and worth a mention. And the voices are cast perfectly as well...like the voice of Willem Dafoe for Gill, for example...a perfect choice. The character of Dory ( speaks through the voice of Ellen DeGeneres ) steals the show. She's an adorable blue fish who suffers from amnesia. She forgets what she's doing or going to every five minutes and that really leads to hilarious situations.

Movies like this aren't just being made for children exclusive... They're good for everyone to realize you have to entertain yourself from time to time and just to enjoy the little things in life. I recommend this to everyone in the world. No matter if you're 9 or 99 years old, Finding Nemo will bring a smile on your face and leave behind a warm feeling in your heart.

Title: Acting great, movie not so much at times
Review:
The vocal talents in this film are great. I love the way Ellen DeGeneres portrayed Dory. Perfect actress. I find that, at times, the only thing keeping the movie funny is Dory. I found the plot strong but the execution weak in places. I like the movie and I've watched it a few times, but it's not a movie I'd watch over and over. It was a big hit and it'll be around for a while.

I was disappointed in the way that the director chose to portray several scenes. A couple of scenes (or animated motions) are repeated in the exact same way throughout the film. If the script calls for the same text to be repeated, it's okay to repeat it, just don't repeat the entire animation.

Title: Disappointing
Review:
I'm one of Pixar's greatest fans, but this film was a serious disappointment (I was even looking forward to the flight!).

The animation was, as you'd expected from Pixar flawless. As a scuba diver pretty well everything looked right and felt right - even the transition from reef to sandy bottom was right on the button!

*However* what happened to the story/script and character development? In this respect it wasn't a patch on Pixar's other films. It fell into classic (note with a small 'c') Disney territory - simple story, great for little kids but what about us big ones?

Title: Right up there with Toy Story and Toy Story 2; well-animated with a good plot.
Review:
Finding Nemo was an excellent film, in my humble opinion, from start to finish. I walked into the theater without particularly high expectations. Since the trailers had told us absolutely nothing about the movie, I actually assumed that Dory and Marlin were man and wife (or something); I questioned how a movie of any length could be carried entirely by a fish's search for his son. I must confess that my expectations were completely exceeded. I was blown away.

I'm not going to sit here and summarize the movie for you; just go watch for yourself. (133/135 favorables at RottenTomatoes.com, for the record.) But I will say this: this is not just a kid's film. I'm a 19 year old girl, and I think it's safe for me to say that theoretically I shouldn't empathize overmuch with either father or son (being a far cry from a kid aching to go to school, or a fretting mother). It was funny and exciting, following in the tradition of Pixar films, with jokes for all ages. You know you should expect the happy ending, but certain moments still make you jump and fret a little or sit at the edge of your seat.

Of course, the animation was brilliant. Kudos to the CGI team and RenderMan for a job well done. The water program is very nice, the coral reef brilliant and teeming with life. The scenes from above the water were photorealistic at times. And beyond the computer animation, I'd like to offer a few thanks to the team that made the water gravity work (things fall in water, even fish; they just fall differently) and the fish move. I've hardly seen anything about it, but the movements are very realistic and follow the real patterns of fish movement (Dory swims in short spurts; "Built for speed" as she puts it; Marlin rows with his tail and uses his fins in an alternating pattern). Nemo's movement is different, as well; he swims with more of his body to make up for his bad fin. It's seamless, and thus hardly noticable.

The music is whimsical and has a bit of a dreamlike quality. When Marlin loses the boat the music makes me think of a bad dream. I really love the score; I bought it today, and now I like it even better. :)

Themes, themes, themes. Every movie has to have one, and the most frequent complaint seems to be that Finding Nemo's theme is shallow. I don't know much about making a good theme, but I will tell you that what theme there was acted as wonderful character development. There's bravery, friendship, and parenthood stuff going on in there. It stikes a chord partially because those on the developing team know so much about letting children grow up, since many of them have kids, too. I think the feeling the producers put into the film comes through in the film itself, anyway.

On the subject of character development: If Dory was the comic relief, then Marlin was the one that carried the movie. There are those that find Marlin annoying, and those that feel Albert Brooks is undistinguished in this role (apparently Marlin is the quissential Brooks character), but while Dory made me laugh, I always wanted to know what was going to happen next with Marlin. His constant fretting just made sense to me; this is his son we're talking about after all, and Marlin is keenly aware of how much personal danger he is in when he leaves the reef. (He and Dory almost get eaten six times, if you consider that the jellyfish are indeed 'trying' to eat them.) Also, it's understated, but the fact that Marlin leaves the reef is a huge deal for him, being something of a coward; and outside their anemones, clownfish are completely defenseless. Besides, Dory really helps balance out Marlin's pessimism.

Dory/Marlin interaction is funny, actually; Marlin is always the parent with these two. He has to be. And he does indeed equivocate Dory with Nemo in his mind, on some level, as demonstrated in the belly (or mouth) of the whale. But Dory teaches Marlin some things, and Marlin teaches Dory a little, and the audience is thoroughly entertained by their banter in the meantime.

I thought all of the voice acting was brilliant, actually. Degeneres cracks me up. Whale scene; enough said. It apparently took her two days of speaking whale to produce all that. Albert Brooks may have been built for the role, but he's all the better for it. His voice almost breaks in all the right places. Honorable mentions go to Alexander Gould, who really managed to project himself into Nemo. One tends to forget this is a kid's voice-acting. Geoffery Rush, the pelican, is a brilliant character. I only wish there was more of him. Willem Dafoe; do I really have to say anything? Brilliant as always. Crush is voiced by Mr. Stanton himself, and all I have to say is 'Duuuude'. My friends and I have been saying "You were like, 'Woah!', and we were like, 'Woah!!', and you were like, 'wooooah'," for days now. Very, very nice.

To quickly compare it to other Pixar films, I'd say this was more ambitious than any of the other films in terms of scope, and more ambitious than every film except A Bug's Life in terms of choice of protagonist. (A movie about fish. Come on!) Depending on your taste, you might like any of the other Pixar movies better, but I'll say now that if Toy Story and Toy Story 2 are my favorites, Nemo is right up there next to them.

My rating: 5 out of 5. Brilliant, witty, goofy, adventurous, and even a bit suspenseful. Well done, Pixar. Well done.

Title: Why I think this movie is horrible in terms of creativity
Review:
Notice I didn't say, "Why this movie sucks." I am merely stating my opinion, people. And for those of you who say the Finding Nemo message boards are for people who LIKE the movie--you are wrong. The message boards are supposed to be ABOUT the movie, and that's all. The following message DOES belong in this message board, even though it is a negative message.

Why I don't like this movie (and many other CGI's):

1) Pixar: "Well we've done a movie about this, we've done a movie about that, now all we need is a movie about fish! But it won't be hard, we'll just take the themes from our other movies and put it underwater."

2) Pixar movies all have the same unoriginal puns in them, and those puns are the only reason the movies are considered funny. A fish in a Pixar movie would say, "Give me high fin!" instead of "high five." It's really unoriginal and as un-clever as "un-clever" can be. A place in a Pixar movie will say, "Give me high wing!" A Bug's Life had another awfully uncreative pun: "Shoo, fly, don't bother me." And the funny part? He said it to a fly! HAHAHAHAHAHA, get it?! Jeez, Pixar is ridiculous. Toy story and Ice Age are really the only clever ones out there that don't rely on puns for humor. Superhero Pixar movie: "Eat your vegetables so you get stronger." HAHAHAHAHAHA! He's ALREADY strong! HAHA!

3) Dory: more annoying than Chris Rock's voice, more annoying than Chris Tucker screaming at Ice Cube. More annoying than the fact that almost all of the children's movies out there today are CGI.

4) Even in the movies where the characters are HUMANS, they STILL are trying to replace regular animation. CGI art is easier than pencil; computers automate a lot of the movements of things. The artist sets a track for the fish fins to follow, for the tail to follow, for the body to follow, hits okay, and boom, you got a fish swimming.

5) And again, for emphasis: same jokes as every other Pixar movie out there.

Title: A got to see!!!!!
Review: The pix-tar film Finding Nemo was one of the most entertaining movie i have seen in a long time.The film was directed by Andrew Stanton and Lee Unkrich.Finding Nemo is a cartoon so there are no real people actually in the movie besides the voices of each character. But each of the actors that did each voice did a wonderful job and should be very proud of the job they did in the film. . There are three main characters in this movie, Marlin which is the father fish, Nemo in the little kid fish, and Dory which is Martin's friend that he finds on his journey he takes. The voice of Martin in played by Albert Brooks which I thought did I great job playing the strict worried father role throughout the movie. The voice of Dory is played by Ellen DeGeneres, which is the best role in this movie. She fits the characters scrip so well it seems like she is really the fish in this movie not an actual person. Ellen keeps you laughing almost the whole movie with her voices and little side humor that some people pick up on and some don't. The last main character is Nemo the son of Martin and is played by Alexander Gould which isn't really a huge actor in the Hollywood scene but did a wonderful job in the Pixar film. His character is a little clown fish that gets lost and has to be found by his father before something else happens. The plot of finding Nemo is wrote very well by the directors. There are many parts in the movie that make you laugh your pants offand other parts that might mae a tear or two come out of your eyes. If you are bored or have a date that wants to watches a funny cartoon movie Finding Nemo is one to see. I don't think anyone in the room wouldn't want to watch the beautiful colors of the Pixtar Film.

Title: stunning animation with intelligent story about a piece of life
Review:
The first time i watched 'Finding Nemo', all i could do was just laugh and laugh... 'cause you can never ever control that!!! it was a complicated feeling i felt then... and still i am amazed by the complexity that the movie has.

'Finding Nemo' is a breakthrough. It's not just about celebrating the creative art work of the professionals, it's more than that. 'Finding Nemo' is a true animation with all that intelligence, taste, and all good things that come in minds of anybody around the world. I think it's like the best modern animated movie that stun people's eyes and mind.

You'll never know how you can even forget about how funny dory was. I mean... all characters are also very special, unique and they build up this animation into something so much real. It's just too real that somehow it makes me think that Those fishes can talk. You know how dory's actually trying to talk with a whale... and for God's sake, she can!!!

'Finding Nemo' itself really speaks. It has so much meanings that we can relate them to our lives. It's... you know... AMAZING. How Fish actually more humanity than a human itself. Hahaha... yeah, that's for sure!!!

This is gonna be like 'Beauty & The Beast' that was nominated as the Best Picture at Oscar several years ago... u see how those critics comment about 'Finding Nemo'??? They give 'FN' the A grade.., almost all!!! better than they actually give to those films that's gonna be predicted to being nominated as the best picture 2004 like mystic river and master and commander.

let's see how 'Finding Nemo' can lead its way to Oscar 2004!!! I bet that it's gonna take the trophy. At least for Best Animated Feature. And I hope it's gonna make steps to the Best Picture, best original screenplay, best original score and song and best art-direction/set decoration or even best director... Let's see!!!

So, u agree with me???

Title: Great Film!
Review:
Finding Nemo is a great film. It is packed with a lot of humor! It also has some parts that can sadden children, but overall it is something that the family can enjoy.

I guess some irony can make the movie interesting, like a shark on a 12-step program to become friends with fish or a pelican telling a fish to hop in it's mouth to save it's life.

The movie opens up with some sad scenes, like Nemo's mother (with the eggs) getting eaten by a barracuda. Nemo is the only child of Marlin, who is now overprotective of his son.

Well, I won't spoil the movie for you, but I have heard from others that, even though it's rated G, some of the younger children did actually cry during the movie.

Well, overall, it was a great movie with amazing graphics. It's no wonder they spent a long time working on this project, but it did pay off.

I rate this film a 9 out of 10.

Title: Totally Excellent, Dude!
Review:
This is the BEST movie from Pixar yet. The story line was well thought out, and excellently executed. I was worried that parts of the movie would be too intense. However, the humor that infused the entire movie kept this from happening. Finding Nemo is the best kind of comedy. Totally unlike so many comedies today, where you have a few really funny scenes connected by long periods of not funny. My husband commented that this was the most continuously funny movie that he had seen in a long time. I personally did not expect to like this movie. I don't care for Albert Brooks, or Ellen DeGeneres, but the movie itself distracted me from who was doing the voices.

My two girls, 7 & 9, loved it. My youngest really enjoyed the scenes with the sharks, the turtles and, her favorite part, the whales. My oldest enjoyed the way Marlon and Dorrie escaped from the sharks, and the way the movie ended. We will be purchasing this one when it comes out on DVD.

Title: Warning! Not just another Pixar Fun Film!
Review:
In `Toy Story: we were treated to a hip, fresh view of life from the toy's point of view. Ditto for `A Bug's Life'. `Monsters Inc' rounded out Pixar's penchant for getting inside the head of the imaginary and creating an intriguing world that.sucked us in and took as for a great ride.

Enter :'Finding Nemo'. It is here Pixar has dropped the ball. Do we get a fresh, unique perspective of life from the Fish point of view? Nope. Fish swim, they are afraid of predators, and well, that's about it. The ocean is a dangerous place, a theme repeated with boring redundancy throughout the film. The plot slogs along from one anxiety invoking mishap to the next, with little humor intervening. What little humor there is comes across as weak. The scene with sharks in an AA type meeting swearing off fish as meals simply doesn't work. I guarantee you will check your watch in the first 30 mins, then regularly thereafter.

I understand kids movies are to be simple and funny, with the occasional sad parts and near misses. This is more near misses and sad parts, and I just expected much more from Pixar in terms of story and imagination. The animation is absolutely breathtaking, and the acting is excellent. Too bad the underlying skeleton is so weak.

I see the next Pixar film, slated for November, is `The Incredibles.' It has a different writer, so hopefully we'll have shot at getting things up to snuff.

Title: The bar has been raised yet again.....
Review:
Just when you thought it couldn't get any better, along comes Nemo. Maybe responding to the gauntlets thrown down by DreamWorks (Shrek) and Fox (Ice Age), Disney/Pixar have come out with their most visually stunning and most emotionally moving film yet. The humor, small details, background action, and minor characters (the gulls really cracked me up!) provide the richness that make this a definite see-again. But maybe the best compliment is how thoroughly I forgot the CG wizardry and was drawn into the world of the characters. You don't need to know it's computer animation, it's just *animation*, and it keeps getting better all the time.

Can't wait to see what those folks will come up with next....

Title: When will they find the fish so I can go home?
Review:
Unfortunately, I went into Finding Nemo with high expectations. By the end, I left wishing I had just taken a good nap at the theater rather than waste my time (it felt like roughly 12 hours) watching this insipid flick.

The movie made me smile a couple of times (mostly at the forgetful fish), and, if it had been written as a fifth grade class project, would have had an impressive plot. The surfer turtles - lame. Overprotective dad - boring. The bad fin on Nemo - come on! Any potential actual laughing the movie might have engendered was wasted by the fact that I had seen all of the funny scenes approximately 1,721 times in commercials and previews.

As positive a review as I can give: "Cute film your kids might like. Good animation"

Real Review: "Waste of time and money. The whole family would have a much better time at the zoo watching monkeys fling poop at each other."

Title: Pixar has done it, once again...
Review:
I remember when I saw the first few trailers for this, I thought that Pixar may have made a movie that wasn't up to par with the others. However, I decided to see it, just because it was Pixar, and I hadn't yet been let down by any of their movies. I sure was wrong in thinking that this was going to be bad!

The movie starts out on a rather dramatic note, but soon, the humor kicks in, especially with the introduction of Dory. She provides much of the humor, but it isn't just her that makes this movie great. Marlin is Nemo's overprotective dad, and he provides a bit of humor as well. The voice acting is spot on, and Ellen Degeneres (Dory) and Albert Brooks (Marlin), do excellent jobs with these characters. What is even better is that the jokes are not just for children; they are pretty enjoyable for adults as well...(I'm a teenager, and the audience I saw this with was mainly made up of adults...without kids.)This just goes to show how great Pixar is.

The computer animation is also quite stunning, from the backdrops of Sydney, Australia, to the murky look of the ocean water in some scenes. I have to admit that I was quite impressed with several scenes in this film.

The minor characters are great as well. The fish in the aquarium also provide for plenty of laughs. The character of Darla, with her introduction including the 'Pyscho' shower music, was pretty interesting as well...She kind of reminded me of Sid from Toy Story.

Anyway, Finding Nemo is an excellent, well-made flick, and it is probably the best movie so far from Pixar. This is definitely one that you should catch in theaters.

The best movie that I've seen so far this year....9/10

Title: Very Inspiration Movie!
Review: I thought Finding Nemo was one of the best films I have ever seen. Not only did it have excellent animation but it also had a heartwarming story as well. If one were to peel back the layers of this story, some powerful lessons in the game of life could be found. Although the main characters are portrayed as colorful tropical fish, it is easy to apply these messages to ourselves as well. Two lessons from this movie were especially appealing to me. The first was Marlin and the way he overcame his fear of leaving his home and losing sight of his son Nemo. That is quite understandable, for Marlin had gone through a very tragic incident with the destruction of his mate and all but one of his eggs. When Nemo was taken away by divers, he did not just give up and accept that he would never see his son again. He went after his son, faced his fears, overcame enormous obstacles, and discovered the value of trust with another fish he had befriended along the way. The next lesson occurred when Nemo got stuck in the filter and Gill insisted that he get himself out. Nemo assumed that his gimpy fin was an obstacle and would therefore make it impossible for him to get out. Also, his dad always helped him in those situations. When Nemo got himself out, the expression was of confidence and pride. A disability does not mean that person can do less than anyone else. The values of trust, letting go, and facing your fears in the setting of the fascinating ocean environment, along with the comic relief of Dory, proved an ingenious way of making an excellent film. I hope viewers will take the opportunity to take the messages to help themselves grow as people. I know I did.

Title: Finding Nemo
Review:
Finding Nemo is an animated film created in 2003 about the father â€“son adventure through the mysterious wonders of the ocean and the new discoveries of the land of humans. The story begins as Nemo (voice of Alexander Gould) is the only survivor after a shark attacks his mother and the other eggs. Nemo's father takes Nemo under his fins and they begin their new life together. The story unfolds as Nemo is taken by humans from his home on the coral reef. Nemo's father Marlin (voice of Albert Brooks) sets out on his journey to find Nemo and bring him back home. Nemo becomes entrapped in a fish tank, in a dentist's office, where Nemo learns that he is the new present for the Dentist's niece. Nemo befriends the other fish and together they make the escape from the land of humans to the deep waters of the ocean once again. The battles that Marlin and his new found friend Dory (voice of Ellen DeGeneres) encounter on their journey through the dangerous waters will capture the audience's attention and will keep the kids guessing on what will happen next. The vivid colors and real life sounds create a world of imagination and fun as the audience becomes entranced with the feeling of swimming right alongside of these new found friends. Finding Nemo is a family movie that tells the tale of a father -son bond and how far someone will go to save the one they love. We see the theme of defeating all odds and overcoming all obstacles for those you love while battling hand in hand with strangers that they now call friends. We saw how Marlin and Dory survived the chase of a vicious shark and escaped the jaws of an anglerfish as they stayed determined to find and rescue Nemo from the unknown dangers of the open sea and land. The extraordinary will power of Nemo, a young fish, has overcome all the challenges that life has thrown at him and will leave an impression on many young viewers.

The way that the film transitions from Marlin and Dory's journey to the journey of Nemo allows the audience to see the struggles of both audiences while keeping tabs on what is going on. It also creates the anticipation and the importance of overcoming the dangers they encounter. The fast motion allows for the audience to become involved with the multiple life threatening chases that the characters run into without making them too long for a young audience to keep attention. The elaborate colors and the sounds help the audience to become involved and really feel like they are on the journey with Nemo. The darkening of the ocean gives the impression of the deepness and the dangerous parts of the ocean that Marlin must travel to get to where he needs to go, once again seeing the perseverance of Marlin and what he is willing to do to get to Nemo.

Title: From a 40-something
Review:
I have come to expect entertaining and visually engaging family fare from Pixar. "Finding Nemo" was that and more! I was awestruck by the underwater effects. I was touched by the story of a father searching for his son (my young son sat next to me as we watched the film). I was impressed by the vocal performances; these actors weren't simply reading lines, they were interpreting the roles. Perhaps this film warrants only a nod of respect from 20-somethings, who acknowledge the technical accomplishments, but take it from this 40-something, this film deserves generous applause for delivering something that connects as well as entertains. Perhaps this accounts for its staying power at the box office?

Title: Journey to the Ends of the Ocean
Review:
In the film "Finding Nemo", there are many scenes and events that capture the attention of any viewer of any age. The movie begins in the ocean with a clown fish and his wife. There were expecting hundreds of children together, when something tragic happens to the mom and all her baby eggs, all but one egg died. The clown fish promises to keep that baby safe no matter what and he names him Nemo. The father fish takes Nemo to school one day, and while at school Nemo gets captured by divers. The father fish searches the entire ocean looking for his son, and on his quest to find him, he makes interesting friends and learns many things about the ocean. When the father fish finally finds his son, he is being flushed down the sink because he is "belly up." Father fish decides that he has nothing else to lose, and slowly makes his way back to his home in the coral. When the movie takes a turn for the unexpected, the audience cannot help but to stay and see what happens.

Directors Andrew Stanton and Lee Unkrich try to show the audience many meanings. Some of the meanings would be directed towards adults and some to younger children. One meaning that they portray very well in this movie is the meaning of family value. They show that family is important because the father was willing to go to the ends of the ocean to find his son, and he was willing to do whatever it took to find him. Another meaning which the directors portray is that determination can take us to wherever we want to be, as long as we try. In many scenes in this movie, Nemo or his dad take many risks to achieve something. They both are determined to find each other and to come home safely, and with the determination, they find success and they find out about who they are.

This movie is one of the best movies that I have ever watched. I love that the movie shows a relationship with a father and a son. In most Disney movies, the relationships are between a mother and a daughter. I also enjoyed this movie because the color and images of the ocean were appealing to the eye. The vibrant colors keep a young child's attention and they also match descriptions of what the ocean really looks like. Another reason why I enjoy watching this movie is because the humor that is used can be understood by adults and by young children. I would recommend this movie to anybody who asks, and I would also tell them to be prepared to watch it numerous times.

Title: Another (Searching For/Find) Pixar film!!!
Review:
I'm sorry but this film was disappointing! It was of course a great looking film full of eye candy, but plot wise it was little different from the past Pixar films... yet again the main character has to go and search for or find someone!!!

Toy story - Search/Find our way back to Andy's home Toy story 2 - Search/Find Buzz! Bugs Life - Search/Find bugs that can help Finding Nemo - Search/Find a fish with a tiny flipper

I don't know who to blame for this lack of originality... Disney or Pixar?! I have loved every film they have done so far... don't get me wrong I enjoyed Nemo for the first 10 minutes. But it just hit me how similar these films are! I kind of hate myself for realising that too, because I so wanted to enjoy this film. Instead I found my self rolling my eyes at most of the events that occurred. I'm sure this film will entertain the under 16's which is the target audience. I just wish as with the other Pixar films there would be something there to entertain the more mature crowd. I'll try and end by saying if I had to rate this film out of 10 I would give it a 6.

As a little side criticism I thought Disney/Pixar missed a good opportunity to raise awareness of water pollution with this film. It made the ocean seem like a sparkling clean place, with no environment concerns. A little bit of awareness within the film would have been a nice touch.

PS. After saying all this, I have to admit the gulls were some of the funniest characters I've seen in a Disney/Pixar Production.
